DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Environment, Recreation and the Arts Committee

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, I present the committee's report entitled Working with the environment: opportunities for job growth, together with the minutes of proceedings and evidence received by the committee.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report I have just tabled arises from an inquiry which began in May last year when unemployment was at peak levels. The committee saw a real opportunity through this inquiry to identify specific proposals which would create productive sustainable jobs and at the same time protect our environment. Job creation and environmental protection are both urgent national priorities. Although the number of persons in employment has significantly increased since the inquiry commenced, unemployment, with its terrible human, economic and social costs, remains tragically high.

PARA.TAB: The committee found that in almost all situations there is a need for environmental and economic policies to be better coordinated and integrated. The rhetoric of ecologically sustainable development is gaining acceptance, but policy development and program delivery are still carried out in comparative isolation in the separate parts of the Commonwealth administration that are variously concerned with environment protection, industry development, economic growth and employment.

The committee has endeavoured to identify ways of achieving more effective integration of environmental and economic policies. To this end, many of the recommendations in this report propose new mechanisms and consultative arrangements to bring together the various elements of the administration.

This need to integrate environmental and economic policies reflects the broader need for a paradigm shift in society's attitude towards employment and the environment. A conflict between caring for the environment and jobs is not inevitable. Environmental responsibility and sustainable productive employment can be combined. Essentially, protecting the environment creates jobs. Most sectors of industry have already recognised that protecting the environment through cleaner production is not only good for their corporate image but good business and can generate increased profits.

Responsible environmental policy is likely to lead to a net growth of employment because, first, additional care for the environment is likely to ensure a substantial expansion of work; second, environmentally sound technology is commonly more labour intensive than older technologies; third, the environment industry offers considerable opportunities to increase exports; and, fourth, environmentally sound policy enables productive processes to be sustainable in the long term.

Although cleaner production in industry can lower costs, its job creation or potential for maintaining jobs is not always immediately quantifiable. Overseas experience has demonstrated, however, that investment in cleaner production by industry can not only cut production costs but also provide a substantial stimulus to the pollution control and waste management industry.

Without doubt, there are considerable opportunities for the development of a substantial environment industry in Australia. Worldwide, the environment industry is already larger than the aerospace industry. Along with information technology, environment management is set to be one of the growth industries of the nineties, and this is likely to continue into the next century. There are particular opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region, as the growing newly industrialised nations remedy the severe environmental problems which have resulted from their recent rapid economic growth and urbanisation.

Growth of the environment industry will create jobs. On the basis of conservative OECD estimates of industry growth, the Australian pollution control industry alone could generate 20,000 jobs by the year 2000. On a more expansive note, if Australia could capture only two per cent of the world market by 2000, the $8 billion of business activity could generate some 150,000 jobs. The opportunities are there. The challenge for government, industry and the community is how to best develop them. Essentially, rhetoric must be replaced by action to overcome Commonwealth and state demarcation problems and bureaucratic inertia. There is a clear need for the Commonwealth government to demonstrate leadership.

Many of the 50 or so recommendations arising from the inquiry are aimed at addressing a number of problems identified in the course of our deliberations. It is important that we do not allow these problems to overshadow the positive factors influencing the growth of the environment industry. Australia has a skilled and educated work force, a well developed manufacturing infrastructure and a tradition of developing innovative technology or adapting technology developed elsewhere. An example of Australian industry moving to take advantage of emerging opportunities is the engineering group ANI, which has established joint ventures with European companies and has environmental contracts worth $2 billion in Europe. The company has predicted that environmental engineering could account for 50 per cent of its revenues by 2000.

It is encouraging that the impediments to the successful development of the environment industry are not an irrevocable part of the structure of the economy but result from poor coordination and a lack of commitment in areas of government, industry and commerce. Specific problems we have identified include the lack of national environmental standards, excessive complexity and inconsistent enforcement of regulations and lack of stable markets for recycled materials and less polluting energy sources.

While recognising that state and local government authorities have major responsibilities for environmental matters, the committee nevertheless recommends that the Commonwealth take the leadership role by developing a national strategy for the Australian environmental industry.

Experience in the United States has shown that community right-to-know legislation has proved to be one of the most effective instruments available for reducing emissions. A major recommendation arising from this inquiry is that the Commonwealth quickly establishes a national pollution inventory as a community right-to-know measure. This measure would complement direct regulation processes and self-regulation by industry and, more importantly, it is likely to prompt companies to invest in cleaner production.

The Commonwealth's fiscal powers could also be used to pursue environmental objectives. One measure examined by the committee was the introduction of tax on emissions of greenhouse gases in the form of a `carbon tax', possibly as a revenue substitute for payroll taxes. Consultants commissioned by the committee concluded that a prima facie case existed that the substitution of a carbon tax for payroll tax would have net economic benefits for Australia, but the evidence was not conclusive and so the committee recommends further study.

The environmental problems facing rural Australia were recognised as being particularly severe and are being exacerbated by the ongoing drought. The committee was encouraged by the wide community acceptance of the national landcare program and has recommended substantially increased funding for the community landcare component of the program. There are also major employment opportunities in establishing and maintaining a national, comprehensive system of biodiversity reserves—as recommended in our previous report—and feral animal and weed control.

The committee has recommended a substantial number of actions to the Commonwealth. In essence these measures are aimed at clearing a way through obstacles, establishing coordinating mechanisms and providing additional financial support so that the environment management industry can take full advantage of the opportunities opening up here and in Asia. In so doing, jobs will be created and our environment protected and restored.

I would like to warmly thank the members of the committee for their cooperation and contribution to the inquiry and all those in industry and the community who prepared submissions and gave evidence. I also express strong appreciation to the committee secretariat for its support and work on this report. Ian Dundas, the committee secretary, managed the inquiry. Alan Burdon and Sue Irvine drafted the report and Marlene Lyons edited the report and arranged for its publication. Others made a vital, highly effective contribution to the completion of this important report. I commend the report to the House, and express the hope that the government will respond quickly to our recommendations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, for the pragmatic and informal way he managed these meetings and hearings which gave plenty of opportunity for other members of the committee to have all the input they wanted. Also, I congratulate the committee secretariat for the work it did in compiling what is quite a significant report on a very important subject.

PARA.TAB: The committee reference, hearings and final consideration made me focus more on the positive aspects of employment opportunities with sustainable development than had previously been the case. In the past, and at times now also, I had concerns about the negative impact on job opportunities of sustainable development's tough environmental standards because of the higher costs this creates in Australia whereby the products are too expensive for export or to compete against imports. But I have always been aware—and I believe that the committee inquiry made me far more aware—that if we are to have a sustainable future for our industries then action is required now to ensure that that will be the case. Hopefully—and this point was made from time to time during the hearings—those environmental requirements are sensible and are phased in.

Looking at the developments since May 1993, it is obvious that more and more of the developed countries are requiring higher environmental standards for products that they import, and that we will have to meet those standards. Obviously it is sensible for us to meet those standards for our own sake as well as for meeting market opportunities.

There are increasing opportunities for our service and manufacturing industries based in Australia as more and more countries elsewhere in the world lift their awareness and their standards, and we have some expertise that will be of help to them and good business for us. Recycling offers employment opportunities but is facing some significant problems in achieving the level we would all desire.

But one of the really heartening developments, in my view, by average Australians over the last few years has been their awareness and their positive attitude to recycling household waste, particularly paper and plastics. However, that enthusiasm and cooperation could be lost. There are already some problems in regional areas because of the inability to have a market price or an economic demand that would sustain recycling at the local community level. So there is a need to create a market for recycled products.

Having recycling mandatory is no use if the material has to be dumped. So the government—one of the recommendations of the committee's report—needs to show a lead with its purchasing requirements, its purchasing contracts, for a sensible range of products where recycling of those materials would need to be an element.

Higher standards for our products are required overseas. Chernobyl, and the subsequent fallout right across Europe, was quite a turning point in consumers' attitudes in developed countries for what we are now promoting as Australian clean and green food. International standards are being applied more and more, whether they are Codex or World Health Organisation standards. There is a recognition that we do have some problems with our own standards in Australia: for example, most of our regional town water supplies do not meet World Health Organisation standards. There is a need to improve that partly for its own sake and partly to meet those market requirements.

As we value add to more of our products than we did in the past—and that is positive for job creation in itself—there is more and more effluent produced. There are now restrictions—and correctly so—on effluent disposal. We did learn of some examples of where it is possible to use the valuable nutrients from effluent to sensible purpose with job creation, forestry, et cetera. This has been done in my own area by the Goulburn Valley water authority.

Landcare has been and continues to be one of the great positives of this country. I have always commended the Australian Conservation Foundation and the National Farmers Federation for working together for its achievement. I claim my part when I was shadow minister for primary industries in ensuring that there was bipartisan support. I draw attention to some of the committee's recommendations that there is a need in real terms to increase the amount available for land care. The figures we are seeing at the moment are not accurate because they are now putting together the original national soil conservation program, which was the original landcare program, plus the water program and forestry items, which were separate items initially. Therefore, we need to pursue that and to recognise that even landcare does not cover the situation of sustainable agriculture on the farms themselves, and that has to be addressed in the future. I commend the committee's report to the parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gave me a great deal of pleasure to participate in the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts which has produced the report entitled Working with the environment: opportunities for job growth. Like the previous speaker, the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd), I would like to congratulate the chairman, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), for his leadership and the continual reminder that we had to get the job done. We certainly did get the job done. I would also like to thank the staff for their outstanding commitment to the task that we had.

PARA.TAB: The report enunciates a number of issues about the environment, and we make many recommendations. I would like to think that it will not be seen simply as rhetoric but hopefully as a guide to a sustainable future, because there can be no doubt that many of our industrial practices, both primary and secondary, in Australia today are not sustainable. As a nation we are placing greater pressure on the environment through population growth, particularly along our coastal fringe. Through the drive for industry to be competitive on an international basis it is very easy to overlook the cost to our environment. We all know that once we have destroyed certain environmental features we cannot get them back.

While some of the industrial excursions left us quite invigorated with the feeling that some of our industries are attacking sustainability head-on—and there is no doubt that they are winning—there were many occasions when frustration showed through and the inertia of inefficient and non-sustainable practices was just too hard to overcome. The state of industry in Australia today shows that some large industries simply do not try to be environmentally responsible citizens.

One industry that has enormous potential in my electorate is the production of ethanol from woody tissue. This industry poses a great future not only for the people of my electorate but for the whole of Australia and indeed for the whole of the world because it is new technology. It will allow a renewable energy resource to be used to provide a fuel that does not depend on fossil fuels and will not be adding to greenhouse gas because it uses current crop biomass.

The government is committed to it; the opposition is committed to it. APACE Research, which gave evidence to our committee, and its chief chemist Dr Russell Reeves is certainly committed to it. But the biggest user of the raw timber resource in New South Wales, Boral Timber, has walked away from it. This is a company that has recently had its woodchip licence increased by half a million tonnes. When companies such as this are not prepared to participate, to take the opportunity to develop new technology, one has to question the value of a report such as this. When large industry, with the enormous resources it has, would not even give $2 million to a project that can turn around the liquid fuel industry in the world, we must really question its objectives.

Australia is in a unique position to develop alternative energy sources, be it solar, wind, biomass or other forms of energy yet to be devised. Unfortunately, because of our relatively cheap sources of energy—coal and crude oil—we have become one of the biggest per capita producers of greenhouse gasses in the world today. As a nation, we have learnt to abuse the processes of nature in this vast and beautiful land of ours. I sincerely hope that our report might convince some of the industrial giants in Australia and some of the bureaucrats in government departments that we have a duty to future generations of Australians to move towards sustainability, because that is the only way that we will have a future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Mr R.D.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak on this report of the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts. I would like to congratulate the chairman, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), the secretariat and also the other members for their contributions. When we look at the terms of reference of the report, we see that it was a fairly wide-ranging inquiry. As we went through the submissions and conducted visits around Australia to discuss matters with many people, I think we realised how enormous the particular task of environmental job growth was going to be and how broad ranging it really was.

PARA.TAB: The environmental industry, to my mind, is a real growth area in Australia, along with the information technology industry. One of the things we have to realise in Australia is the importance of our environment. For instance, by the year 2040 we may have a doubling of our population. Unless we start to address environmental issues now, who knows what the state of our country will be in 2040. So the importance of the environment to the whole social welfare debate in Australia is very important. I hope this report continues the process of debate and discussion on these matters.

Why do we need an environment debate and why do we need an environmental industry? If we look at human degradation around the world, we realise that it is a very important issue. For instance, the World Wildlife Fund no longer only looks after threatened animal species around the world; it also educates people to try to change their way of life in order to help the sustainability of threatened animals. So we are now looking to the people of the world—homo sapiens—to change our whole living process and rethink what we do.

The report identified a number of areas in which Australia is at the leading edge of technology in relation to a lot of environmental industries. I think that is quite good. One area in which I believe we can work is recycling. Recycling at the local level is very good, but unfortunately we do not know how to actually handle it.

We went to a plant in Melbourne to discuss the recycling of plastic milk bottles. The workers there were doing a very good job; they were producing products which were very good. But, unfortunately, the market for end products is not around. We have to start rethinking our whole process in this regard.

There are three points which are very important. Ecotourism is an area that is growing in Australia. It lacks regulation, which we address in this report. A lot of people should be taking a serious look at the ecotourism industry and trying to regulate and protect it. Many operators are moving into the area and calling themselves ecotourist operators, which may not be helpful to the environment. As we attract tourists to Australia, we should have a more serious regulatory look at what we do in ecotourism.

The report also addresses carbon tax. I favour a carbon tax because I think the user-pays principle is good, but only on the basis that it replaces other taxes. It cannot be a disincentive to employment; it must be used as an incentive to employment. In our recommendations we look to replace payroll tax in states; therefore, a new tax on carbon may be beneficial only if it replaces other taxes.

The last thing I want to talk about is the Western Australian government. We have a recommendation in the report about the WA government joining the national body. There has been a lot of debate in Western Australia recently about the WA government not wanting to do so. Recently, on 14 November, the minister in Western Australia said:

SPEECH.PARA: This issue is about ensuring that the power to manage environmental issues in this State remains where it should be—in the hands of West Australians.

I do not think anyone in the community would doubt that. Environmental issues really have to go down to the basic core area of our community: local government, which needs support from state and federal governments. But, in my mind, the whole benefit of our recommendation to the WA government is that the Western Australian government should be leading on environmental issues. By moving into a national forum, it can contribute by leading on these issues. To promote the standards that the Western Australian government projects, rather than being seen as a negative, they should be seen as a positive and, therefore, held up to the rest of the country. The Western Australian government should not necessarily see it as a negative step but more as a positive step.

PARA.TAB: In recent times there have been a lot of reports about the environment with recommendations as to what we should be doing. I think that, slowly, support for these reports is becoming more popular in the community. We should address the environment for the future not only relating to our needs right now but certainly relating to the needs that will exist in 40 or 50 years time when there will be a huge demand on the Australian environment. We should be looking at ways in which to control it. If we do not do so, we may not save it for future generations, which is the whole purpose of this report. Although the report refers to employment, it really talks about our future. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Mr H.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues from the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in commending this report to the parliament. I congratulate the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) as chair of the committee. If it were not for his interest not only in matters economic but matters environmental, perhaps we would not have had this inquiry. He deserves congratulations for bringing it forward as part of the committee's work and bringing the report to the parliament. I also congratulate the staff of the committee. As usual, they have done a stirling job in providing not only the research backup but also the secretarial administrative backup. As the chairman said, this report perhaps calls for nothing short of a paradigm shift in society's attitude to the relationship between employment and the environment. Whilst this report puts forward 54 recommendations, I do not think any of us would see this as being the end of the continuing discussion there needs to be on these issues.

PARA.TAB: It is often assumed that protecting the environment costs jobs. Unfortunately, over the last two centuries since the Industrial Revolution, many have believed this to be true. The Industrial Revolution in Britain and Europe developed at an astronomical pace, without the slightest concern for the despoliation of the environment. If we take the industrial north of England, we see that thousands of factory chimneys poured smoke into the atmosphere and thousands of factories discharged industrial waste directly into the rivers, all with a wanton disregard for their impact on the environment. Eighteenth century legislation providing some protection to employees was wiped off the statute books in the name of the new fashionable ideas of political economy which saw regulation as anathema.

Protection of the environment was not a consideration. Legislators and factory owners were prepared to place their faith in the inexhaustible capacity of nature. It is no wonder that 150 years later people believe that it costs jobs to regulate industrial output. I quote from the honourable member for Fraser's book with John Quiggin—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a free plug.
—Yes, a free plug. In his chapter entitled `Green Jobs', he quotes the Canadian Committee on Future Directions of the Union and states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the long run, the real choice is not jobs or the environment. It's both or neither. What kind of jobs will be possible in a world of depleted resources, poisoned water and foul air, a world where ozone depletion and greenhouse warming make it difficult even to survive?
I think that is an important encapsulation of the issues that confronted the committee and confront society as we continue to debate the problems that this report covers.

PARA.TAB: One of the issues that has been raised by previous speakers in their comments on the committee inquiry is the need for environmental standards. The honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) has acknowledged, as we have in our recommendation, the need for the Western Australian government to perhaps reconsider its position on some of those issues.

As our report says, environmental degradation is a national problem, and we were urged as a committee, and urged to recommend to government, that measures for its alleviation be pursued on a national scale. It would be most unfortunate and irresponsible for opportunities for job creation in the environment industry to be hindered by any lack of commitment by the Commonwealth and state governments to national strategies. So what we see as yet another policy issue where we are calling for national strategies is cooperation between those elements that make up the federation.

Another way of looking at what we have to do in this debate is the consideration of the effects that it has in generational terms. We have that terminology `intergenerational equity'. In a paper prepared by Denis Hanley, who is a member of the Prime Minister's Science and Engineering Council and chairman of Memtec Ltd, it is stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Clearly today GNP per capita which is often used to compare national wealth does not adequately express the wealth of a nation. However, when assessed in conjunction with a national valuation of the nation's environmental endowment, it provides a more accurate picture of national wealth and would explain why citizens of places such as Australia might prefer to live here as compared with other nations which although possessing higher GNP per capita have a lesser environmental endowment.
We owe our children the chance to have meaningful employment, but this will be a terrible bequest if it comes at the price of the ruin of their environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pleasure to join with other speakers and thank all the participators in the inquiry of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, particularly the chairman, the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), and the staff. The issue of unemployment is much talked about in this place, and I think previous speakers have covered many aspects of it in relation to the environment. The area that I choose to highlight today is point 1.3 in the introduction of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The problems of unemployment are particularly severe in rural and remote Australia due to a large extent to the changing nature of the farming industry and its impact on rural employment.
In the report the Anglican Social Responsibilities Commission of Western Australia is quoted as saying:

Rural poverty is often overlooked, the poor in the bush are the hidden poor . . . The traditional role of male farm labourer has largely disappeared and has not been replaced, this creates a range of pressures in families and communities . . . The picture for young people growing up in rural Australia is bleak . . . Young rural people who leave school to seek work are faced with an ever diminishing labour market. This is accentuated further if he/ she does not want to leave their home town.

That issue is acknowledged on page 1 of the report. I would suggest that in the last decade or so the most interesting thing that has occurred in environmental issues is the fundamental shift that has occurred in rural communities.

PARA.TAB: I think there is an acknowledgment in the report of changing opinion throughout the community—nowhere has it been stronger than in the rural and regional communities—to an acknowledgment that our resources are finite and that we have a responsibility to future generations. The former shadow minister, in his work with the ACF and NFF coalition on land care, was very much part of that, as was I in a regional sense.

I can remember Phillip Toyne and Rick Farley being in a local hotel in my home town in about 1988. We were in the middle of one of the toughest droughts—it is tough enough now, but this was equal to it—and about 100 people from across the Eyre Peninsula accepted the Toyne-Farley proposition put that day that we needed to address the issue of land care. There will always be debate about these things, particularly when it goes to Treasury or the cabinet, or to whomever the responsible person might be. If that cannot be in the form of grants, perhaps we need to have a more lateral thinking process whereby we include all members of the community—all Australians—wherever they live under the land care philosophy.

I think the report is sincere. It does not attempt to portray itself as something which it is not. Various speakers this afternoon have already alluded to some of the conflicts within their electorates and some of the anomalies that this report covers.I recommend that when people are reading the report they look at the changes that are occurring, especially regarding pollution control. As those industries become unsustainable or uneconomic and drop out of the economy, the taxpayer is then left to pick up the mess or the tab. I think that is regrettable. What is involved in the report all the way through is a positive approach to this and a positive way of getting that sea change or, as it has been referred to, that paradigm of change within society to address the issues so that, instead of having the dog chasing the tail, we actually get out there and assist industry and make it possible for industry to change.

On pollution control, the committee recommended that national environmental standards should be outcome oriented rather than process oriented, stringent and rigorously based on scientific grounds. I refer to the recommendation on page 48 of the report, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: While command and control regulations still have an important role in controlling small waste dischargers without the technical capability to properly manage wastes, more flexible regulatory approaches to pollution control can greatly promote economic growth in specific industry sectors and effectively reduce pollution.

That will get me into some trouble with the citrus growers, but the government should recognise that, while we, as opposition members, have been tempted to find all sorts of short cut solutions to the industry's problem which would have embarrassed the government, we have in each of our electorates to date avoided just that.

We call on the government to recognise the dilemma that citrus growers face. We also call on the government to introduce some form of compensation package as rapidly as possible because the compensation package promised has now been delayed for something like five weeks and looks like being delayed another two weeks. This uncertainty is causing the citrus industry a great deal of stress because growers simply do not know what the government is going to do and therefore anticipates the worst, and this very negative anticipation is being reflected currently in market prices.

People not familiar with the industry may wonder what the GATT induced changes are that are so impacting on the citrus industry. It is very simple. The fruit juice industry in Australia has long had an arrangement with the government where any fruit juice product containing more than 25 per cent pure Australian juice was taxed at 11 per cent and any fruit juice product containing less than 25 per cent pure Australian juice was taxed at 21 per cent. So there was a deliberate incentive to use pure Australian juice in any fruit juice drink in order to get the tax advantage.

Clearly, under the GATT arrangements, where we indicate that we will be traders who will trade as fairly and as equitably as possible, it is simply not defensible for us to go on with a tax advantage that deliberately favours Australian products. So the government, recognising its tax obligations, has introduced into this House legislation which says that it will no longer be proper for a tax advantage to be given to processors who use more than 25 per cent Australian juice in their fruit juice drink.

Instead, any processer who uses any juice from any source, as long as it is pure fruit juice to make up more than 25 per cent of a particular drink product, will get the tax advantage of 11 per cent. So there is no longer going to be an advantage for Australian growers. Australian growers are rightly saying to the government, `We as growers are not very fond of GATT. We recognise, however, that across Australia GATT does a great deal more for the nation than it costs and therefore needs to be supported.' For that reason, the growers are saying not that they are resisting this change they do not like but that they are seeking from the government some indication that in an appropriate way it will compensate citrus growers for these disadvantages. We are waiting for an indication of just what that compensation package will be.

Members of the Australian citrus industry have said that it would be reasonable for the government to take 100 per cent pure juice product and give it no sales tax at all. That is the compensation they are seeking. It is not a plea for a particular recognition to the citrus industry; it is a plea for nothing more than tax equity. After all, the government already takes 100 per cent pure juice product—I use the term loosely—in the form of milk and says, `This is a food and therefore will be tax exempt.' Citrus growers are saying, `If it is good enough for pure milk to be tax exempt, it is good enough for pure fruit juice to be tax exempt as well.' Frankly, what is the difference? Both are regarded as food items.

Citrus growers are being very reasonable. They are not asking for a tax exemption on a product that is not pure juice. They are saying, `If what we are producing is not being processed in pure form, it should carry some sort of sales tax, just as any other beverage does.' But in the case of what can legitimately be said to be a pure juice product and therefore food, let us treat it as a food from a taxation point of view, and offer it tax exemption. Of course, this would apply not just to Australian fruit juice but to imported fruit juice as well. It would mean the Brazilian product coming in here as 100 per cent product would also be tax exempt. Australian citrus growers are saying that is fair enough. That is the sort of handicap they have to recognise under GATT but under the legislation the government has before the House we and the Brazilians would all be taxed at 11 per cent. Given the importance that Australian consumers place on fruit juice as a form of beverage, growers ought to be able to treat it as if it were milk and get it sales tax free.

This ought to be a matter of some embarrassment to the government because its own horticulture task force, set up by the government to determine what was in the interests of horticulture across Australia and chaired by Senator Nick Sherry, came out with a recommendation that said, `Any 100 per cent juice product ought to be tax exempt.' We are simply asking the government to pick up the recommendation of its task force in the interests in this instance of citrus growers, but also in the interests of horticulturalists right across Australia.

Why are we propounding what we believe is in horticulture's best interest? It is because horticulture is one of those industries that offers the government great opportunities to increase our export earnings and decrease our balance of payments deficit. For too long there has been this popular view that the citrus industry is some sort of peasant industry coming to the government begging for a handout. It is wrong to have that perception. Everyone should be aware of the fact that the Australian citrus industry that finds it so difficult to compete with the Brazilians in the production of juice is the same industry that takes whole oranges and puts them in cartons and sells them, without any government assistance at all, into the Asian markets, the New Zealand market and even, if you please, into the United States market off-season in the face of competition from around the world.

The industry can claim to be efficient by world standards and to grow a quality product that is appealing and delectable. It can be put in a carton and despatched around the world making money for growers and the government without government assistance. What the industry cannot do, and neither can the industry in California or Florida, is compete with the Brazilians who have become the world leaders in the production of juice and who, frankly, are flooding markets around the world with frozen orange juice concentrate.

The industry is saying, let us recognise that if we are going to put fruit in cartons we will finish up with some sort of overrun because, inevitably, producing fruit of export quality or of sufficient quality to put on the fresh market in Australia means that some fruit will be not substandard, as the essence will be as pure as any other fruit, but will be scarred or marked and will not be appealing to the consumer and therefore will need to find another home. That juice, in Australian terms, will become part of juice production. In the current environment, the Brazilians dictate the price for juice fruit in Australia and a depressed juice price means a depressed price for whole fruit on the fresh market and the export market.

If the government would act to offer the sort of sales tax regime that the industry is seeking—that is, no sales tax on the 100 per cent product, as recommended by Nick Sherry, one of the government's own senators—we would have a situation in which, frankly, we would provide a base juice market on which the local fresh fruit market and the export market could be built. The proposal that the industry puts to the government is not pain free; it still means a great deal of adjustment. It means the industry still has to focus increasingly on the export market but it gives the industry the opportunity for the first time to compete, in juice terms, around the world. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newell Mr N.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to speak to this motion, which I know is of great interest to the citrus industry. This item of private members business is listed in two parts. The first part reads:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)notes the difficulties that GATT-produced tax changes pose for the Australian citrus industry . . .

I do not think the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) will find much argument from this side of the House to the proposition. He will certainly not find much opposition from me. Members of the government are already well aware of the difficulties that our compliance with GATT can bring to the citrus industry and other industries as well. There has already been considerable work done to come up with a range of measures to help the industry overcome those difficulties. The member for Wakefield has mentioned some of those already.

PARA.TAB: The dairy industry, which is very strong in my area, has also had to make some adjustments as a result of our taking up the Uruguay Round of GATT trade reforms. Other industries are consulting with the government as well. The dairy industry has had good consultation with the government over many years on various matters. The last package of reform that went through when John Kerin was the minister was very well received. Now it is negotiating with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Collins, to come up with a package of reforms which will enable the industry to move forward in the last years of the 20th century and into the 21st century.

While I have not been intimately involved with the citrus industry—unlike the member for Wakefield I do not have to declare a vested interest in the citrus industry—I nevertheless have an interest in it. I come from a rural and provincial seat and I lived in the Riverina area for a number of years some years ago. As I understand it, a proposal on the GATT reform packages was to go before cabinet last week but was postponed because of other pressing business. I can assure the member for Wakefield that it still remains a priority for cabinet consideration. The government is well aware of the problems confronting the industry because of the changes to GATT and will be doing all it can, while remaining consistent with GATT, to assist that industry.

For those members who are not aware of the implications of GATT to the citrus industry, I will give a very brief picture. Currently, the Australian citrus industry sells a large percentage of its product as juice concentrate and receives a tax advantage over juice concentrates that are imported. Such preferential tax treatment, which the government has quite generously given over the last few years, is illegal under the agreed GATT provisions and will have to be removed.

This means that we will be competing on equal terms with our overseas competitors who are likely to gain some advantage because of their lower wage structures. The industry itself fears we would lose considerable domestic market penetration because of the increased competition. Currently, some 60 per cent of our domestic production of oranges goes into concentrate. So it is clear that losses in this area would have a considerable impact on the industry.

I have heard some in the industry say we should be ignoring the changes to GATT and keeping the existing taxation arrangements in place. Clearly, with so many advantages for Australia in adopting the GATT guidelines, that is not an option. I am pleased that members of the opposition here this morning, including the member for Wakefield, have not been party to those sorts of calls and have refuted that sort of a basis for action.

As I have said, the government recognises that there will be problems for the industry as a result of these changes. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and his parliamentary secretary, Senator Nick Sherry, have been working closely with the industry to develop measures which will help growers over the current hurdle. These measures are due to go to cabinet very soon. Until they have been through cabinet and approved, and until they have been considered by the industry, it is premature to be talking here today about compensation packages.

Before the details of the government's program are known and before the industry has had time to consider them, it is clearly premature for the coalition to be attempting measures of its own. My call to the honourable member is this: wait and see what the cabinet and the government develop and then discuss the measures with the industry and, if it is not happy or the coalition has any ongoing concerns, come back to us and we will see what can be done to accommodate the remaining areas of concern.

The second part of the member's motion says that this House should consider measures to maximise the industry's export potential. People will certainly find no argument from me or anyone else on this side of the House with those sentiments. It is clear that substantial market opportunities are available, particularly in the fresh juice export area. Anyone who has tasted the difference between orange juice from concentrates and fresh orange juice knows that there is no comparison in quality or taste. This is an area where Australia has a competitive geographical advantage. The Asian and the South Pacific markets for fresh products are growing enormously. With proper industry planning and direction plus government support, we will capture much greater slices of these markets.

Having just come back from Japan some two weeks ago, I think there certainly is opportunity in terms of the price and the quality of fruit there. For example, a mandarin or orange that I would consider to be of poor quality is selling for the equivalent of about $1. Fruit of better quality is being sold for about $2 to $3. In comparing the quality of Japan's fruit with that of our nation, I would say that the $1 mandarin is the sort of fruit that we might get at a well-known department store in Canberra on Sunday at about 10 o'clock at night. The better quality fruit obviously we might pick up during the day when the fresh supply of market comes in.

Much government support is already available. A $2 million program to promote the benefits of fresh juice is under way, and we are involved in a half-million dollar campaign to reduce the pest risk, which has closed many of our market opportunities in America and other potential fresh fruit or juice markets. Just last week Senator Collins announced in the Senate details of an innovative agricultural marketing program allocation to the Original Juice Co., as it is called. This company will receive some $900,000 to help it with the production and export of a premium 100 per cent fresh orange juice product with an extended shelf life. The company has been instrumental in developing a fresh juice sector in Australia and is now hoping to enter Asian markets. The use of innovative processing and packaging techniques will enable the shelf life of the product to be significantly extended. This has important advantages and cost savings in relation to both transport and storage.

We are already part way through a program which aims to eradicate fruit fly. The advantages of success here cannot be underestimated, as I am sure the member for Wakefield is aware. Last year Senator Sherry's horticultural task force report estimated that the value of Australian horticultural exports could treble by the year 2000 and be worth some $2 billion. This was to occur largely through growth in both Asian and American markets.

If the Australian horticultural sector is to take up a major share of these expanding markets and realise the vision developed by the horticultural task force, there is a real urgency for us to tackle impediments to growth in exports. One of the major impediments to growth in fresh fruit exports is the existence of fruit fly in some of our major horticulture producing areas. I understand that areas in South Australia have been able to take advantage of being declared free of fruit fly and have already seen considerable expansion of their export numbers to areas in America.

It is history now that the task force endorsed the working group's recommendations and that the Commonwealth government in its last budget agreed to contribute some $595,000 over four years to that important initiative. There is no doubt from the Commonwealth government's point of view that successful implementation of the tri-state fruit fly strategy will lead to increased export opportunities for Australian fresh fruit exports.

A range of other government programs are available to help those primary industries which compete internationally. The agrifood policy is a good example of that policy. The measures in the 1992 agrifood statement are designed to be industry driven, to foster international competitiveness and value adding, and certainly to position Australia as a major and stable international supplier of processed and fresh food. Particular focus is on the expanding Asian markets with, for example, emphasis on niche markets, brand name packaging and further processing within Australia before export.

The clean food export strategy is another example of policies to actually develop those commercial linkages. The strategy is designed to enhance Australia's image as a supplier of clean, fresh quality produce in overseas markets. It is based on creating a market advantage for Australian fresh and processed food on the basis of its quality and origin from a clean environment. The program is a joint initiative with industry and government funding and is conditional on matching industry funds. The government has given many programs of assistance to the citrus industry. TALK.START.PARA: —I fully support the proposition that the honourable member for Forrest (Mr Prosser) has put on behalf of the citrus growers of Australia. There is no doubt at all that food beverages, be they milk or pure fruit juices, should be treated equally under the taxation system. Because of the changes introduced by GATT, Australian citrus growers should be relieved of the 11 per cent sales tax currently being imposed on Australian fruit juices.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, I believe that there are other things that the citrus industry needs to do. As chairman of the Melbourne Wholesale Fruit and Vegetable Market Trust which runs the Melbourne wholesale market, I was horrified to find that, under the by-laws of the Melbourne Wholesale Fruit and Vegetable Market Trust Act, growers of citrus products in Australia are prohibited from selling citrus products on the floor at the Melbourne market. It is the only horticultural product grown in Australia which growers are prevented from selling direct to retailers at the Melbourne market.

The Melbourne market is the largest grower market in Australia. Every trading day 640 stalls are made available for growers of horticultural and vegetable products. Most of those stands are utilised by two or more growers in sequential arrangements. So we have well over 2,000 growers who sell direct to the retail trade in Melbourne.

I was puzzled as to why a grower of citrus would be forced to go through a wholesaler to get his product into retail shops in Melbourne. As chairman of the trust, I arranged a meeting with members of the citrus industry in Mildura—in the electorate of the honourable member for Forrest. I tried to move to change the by-laws to allow growers to have the option of selling on the floor of the market. To my horror, I was fairly roundly abused by citrus growers because they really want to sell through a citrus marketing board—in this day and age, would you believe!

As far as I am aware, those by-laws are still in existence at Melbourne markets. Growers from South Australia and the Riverina are still prevented by the by-law from travelling to Melbourne, parking their trucks at the Melbourne market and selling their own produce straight off the backs of their trucks. It is a nonsense.

It is time that the citrus industry got rid of this rather quaint marketing notion that somehow it is better off having the wholesaling of its produce controlled by a board. In my own experience, and through my understanding, of the industry I have found that that only assists some large growers. It does very little for the family farm. It does very little for growers who want to produce a different product: because it is controlled by a marketing board primarily controlled by large growers, small family groups are forced into producing the product which the larger growers want to produce.

When I tried to get the by-law amended, the then Minister for Agriculture in Victoria, Ian Baker—a fairly useless individual who did very little for anyone in the state of Victoria—also abused me quite roundly. I found that, from both a governmental and an industry viewpoint, moves which were designed to assist small family farmers and small citrus growers to have access to the retail market were soundly defeated.

I urge the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) and the member for Mallee (Mr Forrest) to talk to their citrus boards and their growers to try to get some more rational approach. If the citrus industry really wants to flourish, it really should open up the rights of growers to sell as they see fit. In this House we all know that the old notion of marketing boards run by agricultural industries has been pretty much a dismal failure in Australia, and this is one organisation which needs change.
