TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)recognises the 50th anniversary of the Bretton Woods Institution by acknowledging both the value of the achievements of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund and the costs of their misjudgments; and

(2)calls for the establishment of an intergovernmental committee with broad representation along the lines of the Committee of Twenty for the task of reconsidering the functioning of the international financial institutions after 50 years and their future role in the dramatically different world economy from that in which they were founded with a view to improving their effectiveness, their coverage and their democratic covenants.

The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have just celebrated at their annual meetings in Madrid the 50th anniversary of their establishment. This is therefore an appropriate time to consider, as suggested in the motion, the value of their achievements and the costs of their misjudgments.

PARA.TAB: The world is at an economic watershed. For the last two decades we have been cursed with a particularly narrow approach to economic policy making, especially in the English speaking industrial countries. Reduction of inflation has been given pre-eminence over every other macro-economic goal, there has been absolute faith in the efficacy of unimpeded markets and there has been an obsession with efficiency and a neglect of equity. Social goals have commonly been relegated to insignificance. The core target of fiscal policy has been cutting public outlays and taxation on higher incomes. The Reagan and Thatcher governments were the clearest examples.

The results are evident for all to see. There have been some benefits. Inflation is now generally low and productivity has improved, although not by nearly as much as would have been desirable. But there have also been severe costs. There has generally been a major increase in unemployment, an increase in the concentration of economic power and a deterioration in the equity in the distribution of income and wealth. Unemployment, poverty and homelessness are manifest on the streets of all major cities in countries which have adopted this fundamentalist stance.

The International Monetary Fund and the World Bank have been active advocates of this approach. They have been impelled to do so by some of their more powerful member governments, and have also been advised to do so by the majority of their professional advisers. As well, the fund and the bank do not act as global institutions: they concentrate their policies on current account deficit, developing countries.

The Western hike in interest rates beginning in 1979 and the consequent crisis in debtor countries enhanced the leverage of the fund and the bank. Under the rubric of structural adjustment they imposed contractionary, deregulatory and inequitable policies on deficit countries. The success of these adjustment programs has been very limited indeed.

Of the 55 developing countries in which these policies were used between 1980 and 1989, 27 experienced a decline in per capita income and, in another 13, external imbalance and debt continued to be unsustainably high. Yet, in another seven, there was clear evidence of declining social indicators. In Brazil the investment rate declined disastrously, severely reducing prospects for sustainable growth. Of the 55 adjusting countries, only seven appear to have adjusted successfully.

Aware of these and other related issues, the Australian parliamentary Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade conducted an inquiry into the bank and the fund in 1991 through to 1993. The committee made many recommendations aimed at increasing the openness of the fund and bank's activities. For example, we recommended that an interparliamentary assembly be establish to monitor the fund and the bank. To keep such an assembly manageable, we recommended that it meet annually and that membership be limited to two members from each of the national parliaments of the countries providing the executive directors of the fund and the bank in that year. The first such meeting is being sponsored by the US Congress and is being held in Washington next Monday, 21 November. This Australian initiative has been adopted by the global community.

The parliamentary committee also strongly recommended that poverty alleviation be the focus of all structural adjustment lending and that the environment, land redistribution and the reduction in population growth rates receive higher priority. We also supported a new issue of special drawing rights by the fund, a recommendation which was discussed at the Madrid annual meetings. We also suggested that, in order to increase the finance available to the bank, it be empowered to borrow more than the value of its capital base.

The parliamentary committee noted that in recent years the bank has been attempting to learn from past experience and to ensure that safety nets are available so that the poorest groups are not disadvantaged by structural adjustment loans. We could not find evidence, however, that the same is true of the fund. We wrote:

SPEECH.PARA: From the evidence presented it is clear that although considerable work remains to be done, the Bank is moving, albeit slowly, in the right direction to alleviate the impact of its adjustment policies on the poor. However the same cannot be said about the Fund. Australia should therefore endeavour to raise the issues of poverty . . . with the Fund at every appropriate opportunity . . . The Committee recommends that the government strive within the Fund to achieve a poverty alleviation focus in structural adjustment lending. Within the Bank the government should press for full implementation of the Bank's poverty alleviation policies . . . and for more resources to be directed to evaluating the poverty impact of these loans.

We proposed that the annual report of the Treasurer to parliament detail more fully how such recommendations might be implemented. The experience with structural adjustment lending demonstrates the danger of policies with goals which are too narrow, involving concentrating on improving efficiency and neglecting equity and giving too little attention to development—for this leads to increasing poverty in equity and unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The most important lesson of the 1980s is about the importance of aiming for simultaneous achievement of goals, of increasing efficiency and equity, of reducing inflation and unemployment, of increasing economic development and of enhancing ecological sustainability. This is clearly a complex task but it is essential to attempt to balance those goals if effective sustainable policy is to eventuate.

Conversations with politicians in other countries suggest that they have the same difficulty in dealing with international financial issues that we have in Australia. That is, these issues are kept tightly controlled by treasury and finance departments and that, given the lack of interest in these issues in the wider community, there is little incentive—let alone opportunity—for politicians to take them up. That is why a debate like this is really important.

Global pressure for change is starting to increase. A clear symptom of this pressure is the agreement by the United Nations to hold the World Summit for Social Development. Institutional arrangements and policies of the international, economic and financial institutions are amongst the concerns which led to support for holding the social summit.

There is widespread recognition of the gaping hole in international economic policy making structures. That is why one of the issues on the agenda for the social summit is upgrading the economic and social council of the United Nations. It has been proposed that an executive committee be established within it which would meet in continuous session and which would have on its agenda the principal global economic problems, such as macro-economic coordination, the volatility of exchange rates, trade, investment and development finance.

New institutional arrangements are certainly required. It is also important to find some ways of reducing the power of the international financial markets to set national economic and social agendas. So a very important issue which is being suggested by our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) and Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Howe) is the possibility of a small foreign exchange levy. This would have the effect of discouraging very short-term speculation, reducing the power of financial markets to set national agendas, reducing exchange rate volatility and generating revenue for national governments and the international community.

It is important to imaginatively examine such policies within the context of the fund so that its effectiveness can be increased. A reluctance to seriously consider such reforms is one reason for the excessive reliance on structural adjustment lending. A more comprehensive, genuinely global adjustment strategy is required in order to facilitate faster economic and social development within developing countries. At a time when the bank estimates that the number of people living in absolute poverty is well over 1,000 million people, nothing else is adequate.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—Is the motion seconded?

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The signing of the Bretton Woods agreement in 1944 was an extraordinary leap of faith. Only three weeks after the D-day landings, financial experts met in a small town in New Hampshire and mapped out a new monetary system for the postwar world. They established a monetary framework of fixed exchange rates based on freedom of trade and currency movements to replace the anarchy of the 1930s; founded a new bank to replace the international capital markets, which had been killed off by the defaults induced by the Great Depression; and laid the foundations for the greatest half century of expansion the world has ever known.

PARA.TAB: Bretton Woods is not just an economic milestone. The economic growth and increase in international living standards it delivered and their implications have influenced all facets of our lives since the Second World War. In 1944, Stalin's armies were beginning their occupation by stealth of eastern Europe and Mao Zedong was still building his rebel troops, the Red Army. Today Russia and China, along with most of the developing world, are belatedly adopting the open trade and financial markets that Bretton Woods sought to establish. In 1994, we should not just mark the anniversary of the agreement. As we look around the world and see the extent to which governments frame policies in line with the principles of Bretton Woods, we should examine the Bretton Woods institutions and their role in the contemporary financial world.

The Bretton Woods monetary system of fixed exchange rates was effectively finished in 1971 when President Nixon suspended the US dollar's link to gold. International capital markets have expanded more than the 1944 conference delegates could ever have expected. The contribution of the World Bank to international lending is now marginal, and the distinction between the bank and the IMF has become blurred.

In the immediate years after the end of the war, the IMF policed the fixed exchange rate system, giving short-term loans to countries which found themselves in balance of payments difficulties to enable them to avoid introducing trade restrictions, while the World Bank lent money to finance large public sector investment projects. After the fixed rate exchange system broke up, IMF approval for overall financial policies became more important than its short-term loans. Its clients also changed from industrial to developing nations, particularly in the 1980s, as the fund helped in the resolution of the Latin American debt crisis.

At the same time, the World Bank became an adviser to developing nations on structural adjustment, helping them move to more market oriented economies and providing loans to finance the changeover. Today, it could be said that both bodies are in the business of telling countries how to run their economies and providing loan money to sweeten the pill.

The two most important policies the World Bank and the IMF advocate are control of the money supply and privatisation. This has led to accusations of externally imposed market fundamentalism without a democratic mandate. In the United States, a group is marking the Bretton Woods anniversary with the slogan `Fifty years is long enough'. Policies that are tolerable when applied to relatively wealthy countries can appear devastating for the developing world. So the groups gathered under the `fifty years' banner have called for fairer international trade, an end to structural adjustment programs, reforms to make the IMF and the World Bank more democratic and accountable, and cuts in or cancellation of debts owed by poor countries.

However, a problem with this approach is that it criticises the operations of the free market as much as how the bank and the fund work. It also attributes an enormous amount of power to the twin institutions that simply does not exist. If anything, the two institutions have become less, rather than more, powerful over recent years. Many governments are more concerned with the assessments they will receive from credit rating agencies, such as Moody's or Standard and Poor's, than the IMF. The World Bank's lending program has been dwarfed by the explosion of available private risk capital, and private loans are often cheaper. The growth of Asian economies where nations have become rich from hard work and saving, rather than foreign loans, has also brought about changes in ideas on how development occurs.

The world economy has changed out of all recognition since 1944, but it has changed to make it closer than ever before to the global cooperative free market arrangements championed at Bretton Woods. The World Bank and the IMF are showing substantial flexibility in adapting their operations to meet these changing circumstances. The tasks of developing or making the transition from communism to the market economy would be even harder without the technical and financial support that the Bretton Woods institutions have already provided.

Technology and the collapse of statism have meant that the world's economies are now integrated not merely through trade and goods but by trade in services, finance and production. We now need international economic institutions that can consolidate this achievement.

We are entering a period in the international economy where the stakes are high. Market reforms in China are offering new opportunities to a billion people. Almost as many Indians are beginning to benefit from economic opening up. Economic growth and low inflation are finally coming to Latin America. Parts of the former communist world, such as the Czech Republic and Estonia, are showing encouraging growth and want greater integration into the world economy.

The World Bank and the IMF, along with their long elusive sibling, the World Trade Organisation, the successor to GATT, now have a crucial role to play. They must help the reformers in the old communist states. Failure here would not just mean a reversion to central planning. As we are seeing, it will mean political extremism, civil unrest, capital flight, hyperinflation and even civil war. They will need to help the extremely poor nations. Infrastructure in the already poor nations of Africa is disintegrating to such an extent that even without misrule, disease and civil strife policy makers are finding change beyond their capacity. As Australia well knows, it will be vital to promote an even-handed commitment to open trade for all, despite the dealings of governments in America and Europe and the concessions that other countries demand.

Finally, the World Bank and the IMF will need to look further than international trade rules and examine the network of international law, covering areas like trade practices, intellectual property, banking supervision and currency convertibility that are such vital parts of global financial system. This has led to discussion over a new exchange rate system.

In the early 1970s the Committee of Twenty held two years of far-reaching discussion aimed at designing a reformed international monetary system, but when this failed it was decided that the floating rate system would continue indefinitely. Floating rates have been workable but subject to volatility and misalignment. However, the old Bretton Woods rules cannot be resurrected. The mobility of capital has made it difficult to manage exchange rates with narrow bands and occasional jumps in central rates.

The experience of the European exchange rate mechanism has shown the problems that new exchange rate bands could cause. The currency trouble here has been a real challenge to the rhetoric of the European Community, exposing the unacceptable political reality that economic union is needed before monetary union and that political unity is needed first of all.

The European experience suggests that our best hope for a more stable exchange rate system lies in leading industrial countries reducing macro-economic imbalances and pursuing greater policy convergences on inflation and other targets. Of course, all national leaders know better than others what constitutes sound macro-economic management for their country. But there are real doubts that government can set exchange rates and maintain them through central bank intervention if markets are determined to raise or lower them.

The solution may lie in the formulation of economically intelligent rules rather than the sorts of arbitrary limits imposed by Maastricht, like international pressure for responsible fiscal policies and far smaller budget deficits. To members opposite I can only say, `Well, over you to you.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to second the motion moved by the honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore), and I commend him for his contribution today. I also commend the honourable member for Sturt (Mr Pyne) for his thoughtful contribution to this extremely important subject. We are in the year of the 50th anniversary of the Bretton Woods agreement, which established the international financial system that we still know and the two predominant institutions around which the international financial system has been built: the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.

PARA.TAB: It is certainly appropriate, as is suggested in the motion put forward by the honourable member for Fraser, that we have a bit of a rethink about the international financial institutions and, in particular, that we consider the implications of internationalisation and the accompanying deregulation that has gone on throughout the world in one form or another. It is quite clear, as the honourable member for Sturt indicated, that the world we now face is dramatically different from the world as it was in the 1950s and that the institutions which have been so dominant in international financial affairs since that time maybe have a slightly different role to play these days and perhaps could even be replaced by different institutions.

The World Bank and the International Monetary Fund were established in an atmosphere of, I would suggest, combined idealism and mutual self-interest amongst the non-communist countries in the world at that time. The basic objectives for the establishment of these institutions were to stabilise the world economy; to assist developing countries with investment—obviously the realm of the World Bank; to assist countries with balance of payments problems; and, in particular, to try to avoid some of the protectionist excesses which had been characteristic of the 1920s and 1930s; and, in association with that, to try to establish a structure which allowed the world to avoid a repeat of the Great Depression. Looked at in that light, I think it is fair to say that we should accept that both institutions have had a considerable degree of success in terms of the charter that they were first established with. In particular, the avoidance of a repeat of international economic chaos that was associated with the Great Depression and unemployment rates as high as a third in developed countries has to be seen as a significant achievement.

However, as the motion put forward by the honourable member for Fraser indicates, these achievements have not been without cost and they have not been without errors. Although it is quite clear that the development of an international regulatory structure for the financial system following on from the Bretton Woods agreement has been very important, it has also had some negative side effects, and we need to keep these in mind as well.

In particular, the World Bank has had something of a predilection for what I would call gigantist projects in the developing world. It has been in love with the huge dam and the huge electricity generating project, when it is becoming increasingly clear that the engine room of growth in the world today is very much with human infrastructure—with things like education—rather than with large concrete or bricks and mortar projects like big dams. The failure of the World Bank to devote sufficient resources to things like education in developing countries stands it to debit.

Naturally, some of these projects had many unfortunate side effects—such as the displacement of large numbers of people—and substantial negative impacts on people in the countries where these projects were being put forward. They were often being developed by authoritarian governments that were simply not responsive to the concerns of people. Similarly, the International Monetary Fund prescriptions for countries in economic trouble have been often rigidly ideological and have involved cuts in social programs.

Both the IMF and the World Bank have operated according to a fairly simplistic economic model. One of my favourite stories is of the World Bank in the early 1970s refusing loans to Korea to develop its steel industry because it was deemed not to have a future in steel; in 1987 the same World Bank was describing Korea as the world's most efficient steel producer.

We can conclude that there has been some improvement in recent years in the World Bank, as the honourable member for Fraser indicated. We now have a radically different international situation—massively increased currency flows, capital flows; increased economic integration with exports and imports in all countries; the collapse of dictatorships and command economies across the world; far greater volatility; a variety of new economic theories that I think are set to displace some of the traditional neo-classical theories; and GATT. There is a lot of thinking to be done. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The House is discussing the 50th anniversary of the Bretton Woods Institution and the establishment of the IMF. The honourable member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) has drawn the attention of the House to this fact in his motion, which we are considering today. Over that 50-year period the original intention of the IMF to provide a process for restructuring following the Second World War certainly has changed. There has been a change from initial rejection and lack of interest in the IMF, and a reluctance of a number of countries to deal with it, to a situation where, because of interview processes, visits and consultative processes undertaken by the IMF, it now has considerable in-depth ability to analyse, and it perhaps has a prospect of influencing the economic policies—political to some degree—and social policies of a wide range of countries.

PARA.TAB: I understand that during this year the financial membership rose from 157 countries to 177. It is very interesting to read the annual report of the IMF and to see its success in evaluating the efforts and success of the organisation. I first of all tend to look at its balance sheet and see how successful it has been in managing its affairs. One would note that a proportion of its loan decisions that it has made have not been well judged. For instance, I draw the attention of the House to IMF members with obligations, as at 30 April last year, overdue by six months or more, by type and duration. For three years or more the top four countries in this category have been Liberia, Somalia, Sudan, and Zaire.

One would have suspected three years ago that all of those countries were predictably a bad investment. Yet the member for Fraser and his colleague have suggested that there is little social conscience in this process but a harsh rationalist economic attitude. I do not believe that anybody with a harsh rationalist economic approach would lend a cent to some of those countries. If one looks at the loans made in successive years over the last two years—not just the last three years—one will see that those countries again are consistently the defaulters in repayments.

If one has a quick look at the political situation in Liberia and in Somalia, one would say that there has been little resolution of their political problems. It seems to me that an organisation of this type would want to have some assurance that there was a prospect of political settlement before investing members' funds. The regime in Sudan is intolerant of any opposition. It is an absolutely totalitarian process. Yet the IMF continues against sensible advice to invest in the central regime. The situation in Zaire and Zambia is well known to members of this parliament.

I would like to draw the attention of the House to these factors. The IMF has endeavoured to establish a regime of good management. Its decisions in many instances have not been good. Its success has been modest. As we look ahead, some of the issues alluded to by the member for Fraser, if the IMF continues, will have to be given attention. The effectiveness, the coverage and the democratic covenants applying to countries to which the IMF makes loans will have to be considered. We cannot always resort to the use of UN peacekeeping corps to solve problems wherever they turn up.

If we are going to have this central process of providing funds to countries in need, to countries that are being damaged or that are in trauma, then there needs to be a wider agenda than the simple agenda of lending money for a return. That is not a rational approach. I reject the tag that has been put on it by the government. There is more to it than that. In many instances success has not been achieved—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this House:
(1)recognises that about a quarter of a million Australians are affected by mild, moderate and severe dementia;
(2)notes that hundreds of thousands of other Australians, who are loved ones, carers and friends of dementia sufferers, are as much victims of dementia as the actual sufferers; and
(3)calls on the Government to provide greater and more effective assistance to all victims of dementia, particularly by:
(a)fostering the establishment of residential care facilities designed specifically to give full-time and specialist care and support to sufferers of severe forms of dementia;
(b)ensuring that home and community care services are operating to allow as many sufferers of dementia as possible to remain at home; and
(c)directing more funding to research into the cause of dementia, particularly related diseases including Alzheimer's Disease, Huntington's Disease and Creutzfeld-Jakob Disease.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the massive numbers of Australians suffering some degree of dementia, there are few of us whose lives have not been touched at least distantly by the tragedy of dementia. Dementia is the loss of cognitive abilities in someone who was previously intellectually able. A dementia sufferer will experience the impairment of functions, including memory, thinking, orientation, comprehension, learning capacity, language and judgment. At the same time, there may be a deterioration in emotional control, social behaviour or motivation. At present, dementia is progressive and irreversible. With the loss of cognitive abilities comes a deterioration in the ability of dementia sufferers to perform the tasks of daily life which the rest of us take for granted. So to varying degrees dementia sufferers must rely on others for help.

PARA.TAB: It is the responsibility of governments to ensure that no Australian suffering from dementia goes without help. Not simply compassion but economic good sense dictates that we enable as many sufferers as possible to remain in the community rather than be institutionalised. If this is to be achieved, services must be available to assist dementia sufferers and to assist those caring for dementia sufferers. When it is no longer viable for dementia sufferers to remain in their own homes it is essential that we have appropriate residential facilities available in which these people can be cared for and live with dignity.

On the surface it appears that the government has the task in hand. At present we are in year one of the government's five-year national action plan for dementia care. At the same time, though, we have a health minister whose recent condemnation of the states and territories for their records on mental illness suggests the deepest commitment on the part of the Commonwealth government to all areas of mental health, of which dementia is just one. Yet, as I have had cause to say in this House before, under the present government nothing is ever as it seems.

Perhaps the level of the government's commitment to the needs of dementia sufferers and their carers is best illustrated by the story of Strathdon Lodge in Victoria. Strathdon Lodge is in the electorate of my colleague the member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge). I am sorry that another commitment has prevented him from taking part in today's debate, as I know that his knowledge of the problems I am addressing today is considerable.

Strathdon Lodge is a facility which caters specifically for the needs of the physically able elderly suffering from dementia whose behavioural deterioration is such that it is no longer possible for them to be either cared for in their own homes or cared for in hostel accommodation. The need for this kind of facility is widely recognised. As Brian Burdekin wrote in his report on human rights and mental illness:

SPEECH.PARA: Evidence to the inquiry consistently indicated that people with dementia in institutional care should be separated from people who are not cognitively impaired . . . The behavioural changes that come with dementia can be extremely disruptive to other patients . . . The needs of dementia sufferers themselves are also very different to those of many other elderly people . . .

Burdekin pointed out that in particular the unsuitability of the nursing home environment for ambulant dementia sufferers can cause the human rights of these individuals to be infringed. Burdekin heard evidence that ambulant dementia patients get `zonked out with medication' or `tied to their chairs' in order to protect both themselves and the rights of other patients. In a purpose designated dementia facility this appalling situation just would not occur. The need for dementia specific facilities becomes even more obvious when one considers that 10 per cent of dementia sufferers are not elderly.

PARA.TAB: As I have said, Strathdon Lodge is—or, more correctly, was—such a facility. Over the past two years Strathdon Lodge has been negotiating with the government to have its hostel level funding increased. Even though the nursing needs of its dementia patients are relatively low, they need constant attention. The subsidy for hostel beds has proved to be inadequate to cover the costs for this level of care. To date, the Commonwealth has refused to help; in consequence Strathdon Lodge will close. The government's lack of commitment to supporting specialised facilities for dementia sufferers is clear, as the Alzheimer's Association has noted:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . adequate dementia care for people with dementia and behavioural problems can only take place at present if the facility is running at a loss or is subsidised by some other means to compensate for the inadequacies of the Residential Classification Instrument and the Personal Care Assessment Instrument.

Having spoken of the need for specialised dementia care facilities, I acknowledge the level of expertise in dealing with dementia sufferers that is being developed in many mainstream residential care facilities. I recently had the pleasure of visiting Resthaven at Malvern in my electorate of Adelaide for the launch of a resource manual for use by carers of dementia sufferers in residential care. This manual has been produced by Resthaven Inc. following a small grant from the department of health.

PARA.TAB: Anyone who cares to read through the manual will not fail to be impressed by the strategies that it has in place to deal with the special needs of dementia sufferers. I have no doubt that the implementation of this kind of strategy is quite adequate to meet the needs of 60 per cent of nursing home residents who, coincidentally, suffer from dementia and the many hostel residents whose dementia does not take a severe form. Yet the fact remains that, for the physically able whose dementia is relatively severe, specialised dementia care facilities are necessary.

The short-sightedness of the government's resistance to the development of these facilities can be matched only by its neglect of the community care system. As I have said, dementia is a progressive condition. Sufferers of milder forms of dementia are able to continue living independently but only if services are available to help them with the tasks that they can no longer perform. Without this assistance, sufferers of mild dementia are forced into institutions prematurely at great personal cost to themselves and at great economic cost to the government and, therefore, to the country. Fortunately, for many of those who develop more severe dementia there is a close friend or relative and often a spouse who is willing to take on the role of carer. Yet when left to fulfil this role in isolation the carer succumbs to exhaustion. As Brian Burdekin found:

SPEECH.PARA: The single most significant cause of institutionalisation is family carer breakdown.

Logically, it is essential that home and community care be adequately resourced to provide the services which will prevent this breakdown from occurring. I am pleased that the government has funded the counselling project for carers. However, the expenditure on this very important form of support is absolutely futile unless these carers can access services which give them occasional respite.

PARA.TAB: As a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Community Affairs, which recently concluded its inquiry into the home and community care program, I am keenly aware of the fierce competition that currently takes place for scarce resources. While much could be done to better coordinate and deliver existing services, the fact remains that there are not sufficient resources to provide the assistance to dementia sufferers and their carers which are needed if dementia sufferers are to be kept out of institutions. This is a situation that the government must find the courage to address.

Finally, I reiterate what I have repeated time and again in this House: if we are to prevent our health system collapsing under the burden of treating the ill, then it is imperative that we fund research into disease prevention. This is particularly so in the case of an illness that we know will increasingly become more prevalent. Due to the ageing of our population, dementia is such an illness.

I acknowledge that, under the national action plan for dementia care, four research training positions were funded by the Commonwealth. However, if there is to be a sustained effort to find ways to prevent and manage dementia, then there must be a comprehensive long-term commitment to funding medical research in general. According to an analysis by Access Economics, in the last budget funding for medical research over the next four years was reduced by nearly $50 million per annum in real terms. Research into dementia will be directly affected by this reduction.

By the government's own reckoning, in just over 10 years time Australia's health care system will be required to cater for the needs of nearly 200,000 dementia sufferers whose dementia will be sufficiently severe that they will require significant levels of care. Unless the government addresses itself to the implications of its own projections, the already inadequate system of community and residential care which currently exists for dementia sufferers will collapse. It is high time that the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) turned her focus from the mental health practices of the states to her own backyard. At present, social justice does not exist for all dementia sufferers.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Snow)—Is there a seconder to the motion?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—The government recognises that dementia is one of the major health problems facing older people today and that none of us is immune—not even Ronald Reagan. That is why Australia now has a health system in place that provides older people, including those with dementia, with many options to suit their care needs. As a government, we must be open to new and innovative ways of approaching the question of dementia care. We must invest with intellectual energy, good practice and human compassion.

PARA.TAB: The federal government places a high priority on this investment. There are some 120,000 older Australians with moderate to severe dementia. About half of these people are in residential care; the other half live at home. The majority receive services funded by this government, regardless of where they are living.

The government has reformed the aged care system in a significant way which provides direct benefits to people with dementia and to their carers. We have moved the balance of care away from nursing home care towards support for people living in their own homes or in hostels. We have massively increased hostel funding, emphasising the provision of higher benefits for people with higher care needs, particularly those with dementia. Hostel funding has increased from $59.4 million in 1985-86 to $316 million in 1993-94.

We have developed a greater range of care choice for frail aged people, including community aged care packages, home and community care, day care, respite care, hostels and nursing homes. We have established 120 regional aged care assessment services which provide a multi-disciplinary assessment of frail older people seeking help. We have improved standards of care in nursing homes and hostels through the introduction of a standards monitoring program. We have introduced user rights initiatives in nursing homes and hostels, involving residents rights agreements in nursing homes, advocacy services, community visitors and complaints officers. We have improved support for carers through respite care schemes and carer information services and by increasing the domiciliary nursing home benefit.

In 1992-93 the government committed $90 million over four years to a national carers strategy. We provided $9.5 million as part of a 1994-95 federal budget initiative to provide better aged care services for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. The government recognises the role of carers in enabling people with dementia to live as successfully as possible in the community. There are a number of services in place for carers, including the range of home and community care services, respite care and carer support groups and the provision of information, counselling and carer training.

One of the main sources of information and education about dementia is the Alzheimers associations located in each state and territory and nationally. Their activities include counselling services, carer support groups and the production and distribution of information material. In 1993-94 the government provided over $6 million to support the work of Alzheimers associations.

The residential aged care system is well equipped to deal with dementia. About 60 per cent of people living in nursing homes and 47 per cent of hostel residents who need personal care have moderate to severe cognitive or dementia problems. Commonwealth policy recognises a wide range of approaches to the provision of dementia care, including special dementia units. Although a small number of providers operate fully dementia specific facilities, current information indicates that close to one in two hostels has a dementia care program. These programs involve a range of activity programs, individualised supports and different accommodation arrangements.

In 1992 the government established the national action plan for dementia care. The plan provides for innovative service provision for people with dementia, counselling services, information services and support for research. The plan will cost $31 million over five years. The aim of the plan is to achieve an integrated and coherent approach to dementia care which addresses the care needs of people with dementia living either in residential care or at home.

The 1994 budget provided $12.4 million over four years to establish special psychogeriatric units within selected age care assessment teams across Australia. This initiative will greatly enhance the assessment of care needs of people with dementia and provide expert advice and hands-on assistance to service agencies. It will also provide top-up funding to ensure that adequate residential care is provided.

The government has also commissioned a research project to examine the particular care needs of people with severe dementia and difficult behaviours. This research has been developed in collaboration with the peak industry association Aged Care Australia, and will assist in identifying effective approaches to care. People with dementia are a priority target group under the home and community care program. The national action plan for dementia care is undertaking a range of activities which will strengthen the capacity of the HACC program to meet the needs of people with dementia and their carers.

The quality of formal care can be crucial to the quality of life of both the person with dementia and the family and friends caring for them and, in turn, can determine how long care at home can be maintained. A `first alert' pamphlet has been produced, which provides basic information about services. The pamphlet is currently being translated into 18 community languages for the increasing number of ageing people and their carers from a non-English speaking background. A training package has been developed to improve the capacity of community care providers to respond to the needs of people with dementia. Implementation of the training will occur nationally over the next two years. The implementation strategy emphasises its integration into existing training arrangements by the end of 1996 to ensure its ongoing availability.

The training package will improve understanding of dementia, the effects of dementia, how best to communicate and aspects of the environment that can influence the behaviour of a person with dementia. Recognition of the importance of this training has been clearly demonstrated by the contributions made during its development by a wide range of people working in the field, including aged care assessment team members, medical practitioners, community nurses, geriatricians, TAFE educators, nurse educators and HACC workers, who, importantly, provide hands-on, in-home assistance. A training package is also being developed for carers of people with dementia to support them in their caring role. People with dementia wish to live as successfully as possible in the community for as long as possible, and their carers support this wish.

In addition to the research to be undertaken as part of the 1994 psychogeriatric initiative mentioned previously, research is one of the key elements of the national action plan for dementia care. One of the recommendations of the plan was that both the National Health and Medical Research Council and the Research and Development Grants Advisory Committee agree to make dementia a priority over the life of the national action plan for dementia care. Both research areas have agreed with this recommendation.

The national action plan for dementia care has provided $860,000 for additional research fellowships attached to established research units under the NHMRC. To date, six additional fellowships have been awarded. The clinical category `mental health and neuro sciences' received the largest share of NHMRC funding in 1994, approximately 25 per cent. The same proportion of $30 million in new funding announced for 1995 is in this area. The new research to be supported in 1995 includes research into the causes of dementia and related neuro-degenerative diseases, including Alzheimer's disease and Huntington's disease and also research on the causative agent of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

The report of the independent inquiry into the use of pituitary derived hormones in Australia and Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease was tabled by the Minister for Human Services and Health (Dr Lawrence) in the House of Representatives on 28 June 1994. The report makes a number of recommendations relating to research on this disease. The government's response to the findings of the inquiry will be announced by the minister shortly and will include some specific initiatives to encourage Australian research into Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

The government's achievements in the area of dementia care are impressive and will have long lasting and positive effects on sufferers of dementia and their loved ones. There is more work to do in this area. We acknowledge that. It is, after all, this government that has commissioned the developmental and research work that I have referred to here today. However, we should not understate the achievements of the government so far, nor the contribution of the service providers, researchers and families already caring for dementia sufferers.

TALK.START.PARA: —It gives me great pleasure to support the motion moved by the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth), although I only have five minutes in which to do it. I congratulate her for putting this matter on the Notice Paper and before the House of Representatives. It is, to my recollection, the first time that a member has done so and it is certainly overdue.

PARA.TAB: It seems that there is some sort of conspiracy of silence on the subject of mental disability. Whilst there are investigations, reports and consultant reports, in the community at large there is a very grudging debate of the issue of dementia in particular. In my own local newspaper, the Gold Coast Bulletin, there is a weekly column written by a psychiatrist who in only last Saturday's edition lamented the fact that Mental Health Day had gone by without a comment from the media—with not a word to inform the community that it was a day to give some attention to the subject of mental health.

One can only speculate on the reasons for this. Part of it is, I am sure, a fear that most people have that they themselves will have this fate befall them one day. The idea of the loss of control, and the helplessness of that, is daunting to all of us. Surely one of the other reasons that we have not paid as much attention publicly to mental health—and dementia in particular—in the past is that it has traditionally been women's work.

I think it is notable that in this debate today there are four women speaking on the subject. When one looks at the gender balance of the House of Representatives, the speakers list seems a little out of kilter. I do acknowledge, of course, that the honourable member for Chisholm (Dr Wooldridge) was originally going to second this motion and speak to it, and I am sure he would have done a good job.

I put down none of my male colleagues, but the care of elderly victims of dementia has been women's work. It has been something that governments have been only too willing to see pushed back into the home, for women to look after either their male partners or their elderly parents. We now know that that is not good enough. We cannot burn out our women, particularly our older women, with this responsibility. The number of sufferers is getting too large for us to be able just to put it onto somebody else. It is now necessary for us to seriously address the issue of public resources that should be devoted to dementia.

I have spoken many times in this chamber on the subject of care of the aged. It is no secret that I have a very large number of Australia's aged citizens living in my Gold Coast based electorate. There are a number of excellent establishments there that care for the aged. However, even they are getting a little old now. To me, it is notable that the very best institutional care I see of dementia sufferers in my electorate essentially takes place in the newer aged care establishments where there are purpose-built sections.
I see other establishments trying to cope with the growing percentage of their residents who suffer from dementia and I also see the very real physical constraints on making that possible.

The honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) referred several times in the course of her speech to the general subject of aged care, and had quite a bit to say about the government's funding of hostels. It is certainly my understanding that a hostel is generally not seen as the appropriate place for dementia patients unless it has a section purpose built for them. It has been accepted that many sufferers of dementia require the sort of intensive care that is more appropriately given—and funded—in nursing homes.

It is highly desirable that those elderly people who can no longer live in their own homes for one reason or another who need to live in either a hostel or a nursing home but who are not themselves dementia victims, not be overwhelmed by having to spend their lives surrounded by those who are so afflicted. I am not suggesting that we should shut them away—on the contrary. Unfortunately, when a dementia section is tacked on to an existing establishment, or an existing section is modified to care for dementia patients, overinstitutionalisation of these patients is the result. The government's own consultants report has shown that $500 million is needed to upgrade nursing homes around the country to bring them up to a reasonable standard to be able to care for the number of sufferers of dementia now in our community. Unfortunately, that money has not been forthcoming.

Finally, I was quite surprised that the member for Macquarie included in her speech the rights of nursing home agreements as a plus for the government in this context. I would not have thought that was appropriate for sufferers of dementia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone who saw 60 Minutes last night would realise what a tremendous problem dementia and its related diseases are. As the honourable member for Macquarie (Ms Deahm) stated earlier, with 120,000 older people with moderate to severe dementia in Australia, the government places a high priority on dementia care.

PARA.TAB: The government has recognised that forward looking measures need to be taken not only to support people with dementia and their carers now but also to develop and enhance models which will provide improved care for people with dementia in the future. A national action plan for dementia care is in place and provides $31 million to bring about real change. These funds are being used to undertake research, to improve diagnosis and assessment of dementia, to provide training and education and to support carers.

At present, 47 per cent of residents in Commonwealth funded hostels have a measurable cognitive impairment for dementia related condition. Mild dementia patients are often in the hostel situation and adequately cared for there. Over 40 per cent of hostels provide specific programs for people with dementia, resulting in more structured, varied, stimulating and supportive environments. In contrast, there are only 15 specialist segregated services for people with dementia.

The issue of different models of care for people with dementia is one that attracts considerable interest and is difficult to resolve. One initiative is the establishment of pyschogeriatric care units to provide expert diagnosis, assessment, advice and support to nursing homes and hostels on dementia. The units will be staffed by people with expert knowledge, and it is expected that these units will be established in most states by the end of the year. The second component, which is very important, is a research project which has been developed in consultation with Aged Care Australia. The research will clarify the care needs of people with severe dementia and disruptive behaviour.

Another vital national action plan for dementia care is to expand training opportunities for workers in community care. About half the people with moderate to severe dementia live in the community, with a combination of support from informal carers such as family and friends and formal services provided through HACC funded agencies.

In looking at the needs of people with dementia, there is another group that the government recognises as having special support needs. These are the carers and the families of people with dementia. Between 1989 and 1993, HACC funding for respite services increased $10.1 million. The Commonwealth respite for carers program was established in the 1992-93 budget. Projects include information, training and support for carers; the extension of day care services for the dementia suffers; and the employment of activity coordinators to provide centre based day care for Aboriginal people who suffer from dementia.

In summary, then, I am proud to be able to emphasise this government's achievements in the area of dementia as part of our overall program of reforming the aged care system. There is more work to be done in this area; we acknowledge that. It is, after all, this government that has commissioned the developmental and research work that I have referred to here today. However, we should not underestimate the achievements of the government so far, nor should we underestimate the contribution of the service providers, researchers and families already caring for dementia sufferers.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the major initiatives in the white paper, Working Nation, to assist the long-term unemployed into employment. Can the minister inform the House of the latest data on the number of long-term unemployed? Are the initiatives in the white paper working?

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Of course, the House would be aware of the very good news that came through last week in terms of the unemployment rate, which dropped to 9.1 per cent—down two percentage points in the course of the last 12 months. It is true that we still have a long way to go—9.1 per cent is unacceptably high—but, importantly, the trend is very encouraging for continued jobs growth as well as for continued falls in the unemployment rate.

PARA.TAB: It is not only that trend that is encouraging from the figures. I am pleased to report to the House that the government is making substantial inroads into the problems of the long-term unemployed. This is the group that we said we would not leave behind in this recovery. I am pleased to advise that today the Australian Bureau of Statistics released statistics that show that the number of long-term unemployed in October fell to 279,000—the lowest level for 32 months. This is a further fall over the month of 14,000 and it is a fall of 51,000—a 15 1/2 per cent fall—over the 12 months to October.

If we compare it with the time when this government was re-elected to office 19 months ago, the numbers of long-term unemployed have fallen by 87,000. During the recovery in the 1980s, by way of comparison—opposition members should just listen to this because it will be important for them to understand—it took five years and 1.2 million jobs to cut the long-term unemployment by this much. In this recovery we have done it with 404,000 jobs in 19 months. The recovery in the 1980s saw the fall in the long-term unemployed recognised as only seven per cent of the total jobs growth. In this recovery it is 22 per cent of total jobs growth.

Our success in cutting the long-term unemployed is no accident. Today's figures demonstrate that targeted measures by government do work in making sure that those the recovery would otherwise leave behind are not left behind. Among the initiatives that are well under way in helping in this task is the job compact, under which we have achieved 53,000 successful outcomes during the September quarter. In addition to that, 60,000 of the long-term unemployed are undertaking training to get them job ready. Since April, 190,000 unemployed people have entered case management either as long-term unemployed or those at risk of becoming long-term unemployed. We are ensuring that this jobs recovery is a recovery for all. The House should take heart from the very encouraging statistics that we continue to record.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the minister to the threatened strike by the TWU, which poses a grave threat to supplies of food, beer, other Christmas fare and family travel during a Christmas period Australians want to enjoy after the ravages of the recession we had to have. Is not this threatened strike due to the Prime Minister deliberately talking up the TWU's 15 per cent wage claim last week and exacerbated by your spineless changes to the Industrial Relations Act, which have placed unions above the law, thus encouraging the very strike which threatens to wreck Christmas? Is it not all also due to your craven pursuit of compulsory unionism within the transport sector?

—That is a pretty poor poleaxing job. How ironic it is that we get a question today from the opposition—and the member for Bennelong of all people—on the subject of wages and the threat of a transport strike. After a decade of unparalleled wage restraint and the lowest level of strike action for 50 years, the lowest since they started keeping records, it is understandable against that background and in this stable environment that there would be some public concern as a result of the publicity that has been given to the claim by the Transport Workers Union. That is made all the more so by the great atmosphere that we have been able to engender in industrial relations through the accord process. The last people who should come in here talking are those people still sitting opposite, the ones who gave us industrial chaos—that is what you were responsible for—wage break-outs and the recession of 1982-83. The member for Bennelong, principal amongst their numbers, is flat out counting the numbers now for another leadership spill.

PARA.TAB: Something that more than anything else disturbs the public about the current union sabre rattling is the memory of the conflict and the industrial relations shambles of the Fraser-Howard period. That is a real concern out there amongst the public. In other words, people are realising how much better off they are under the accord then they were when the coalition was in power, until 1983. One thing that does not change, however, and is not ever likely to change is the behaviour of unions around union election time. I would think that the happiest people at this very moment are the officers of the Transport Workers Union, with the coverage that they see being given to this industrial action and the industrial coverage that is given widely in Australia on the eve of their union elections next year.

That said, the TWU must understand that it is part of the accord process. The accord process commits unions to wages outcomes—and I stress outcomes, not claims—consistent with maintaining an inflation rate at or below the level of our trading partners. The Transport Workers Union will undoubtedly go on pursuing its wage claim, but in the end it will be productivity related outcomes that matter—not wages claims—outcomes that under our system have to be determined enterprise by enterprise. Under the Industrial Relations Reform Act those outcomes are insulated from the award system. That is a great distinction between the present situation under the reform act and that which existed in the early 1980s.

If the TWU chooses to use industrial action to pursue its claims that will be a matter of profound regret. Let me make that absolutely clear as far as the government is concerned. Yet again it must be said that the TWU knows that any legal right to strike that it has is conditional upon 72 hours notice and a process that involves bargaining in good faith. It also knows the right to strike can be terminated where damage may be done to the Australian economy or an important part of the Australian economy.

Unless one is arguing for a return to a centralised wages system—and I know the member for Bennelong is not arguing for that, although anything is possible of him at the moment after his performance last week—one must accept that both wages and industrial outcomes now depend a great deal on the actions of employers and the actions of unions. If either a union or an employer chooses to ignore the rules of the new enterprise bargaining regime established under the reform act, there are plenty of punitive measures under that act to ensure that such behaviour does not occur. For the government's part, we will be quite pleased to see them implemented.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of claims that the government's policies of assistance to families discriminate against single income families? Can the minister inform the House of the validity of these claims?
—You answered that question last week.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baldwin The Hon P.J.

It is quite pernicious codswallop because it is being used to justify arguments for extremely regressive policies, like income splitting in the tax system, designed to redress this alleged bias. PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The member for Sturt, contain yourself.

—These sorts of claims have been made in recent times. Some of those claims are based on a completely invalid comparison between the home child-care allowance and the child-care rebate and on the claim that the child-care rebate is greater in value than the home child-care allowance.

PARA.TAB: Mr Pyne interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I warn the member for Sturt.

—This of course is a completely invalid comparison because the child-care rebate is a partial recompense for the expenses incurred in child care. That is a thoroughly invalid comparison.

PARA.TAB: The key point is that in looking at these things we have to look at the totality of government assistance to families. If we include payments, subsidies and allowances to families as well as those delivered through student assistance, we are looking at total amounts of around $11.5 billion in the current financial year, projected to rise to about $15 billion in 1997-98 when the new parenting allowance comes into effect.

The great bulk of that assistance goes to low income earners. Around 54 per cent of it goes to families with private earnings below $200 and around 65 per cent goes to families with private earnings below $400. So it is very well targeted. It has horizontal equity elements but it also has very substantial vertical equity elements designed to redress inequalities. As I have pointed out to the House on a number of previous occasions, the real value of that assistance targeted to low income families has increased quite markedly.

The other key point about this is that targeting low income families has the practical effect of ensuring that most of the assistance goes to single earner households, for the obvious reason that two earner households earn significantly more than single earner households. If we take the additional family payment of around $3.6 billion, which is the key vertical equity instrument, 80 per cent of that goes to single earner households. Most of that again goes to households where the youngest child is between zero and five. That element of the payment system delivers enormous assistance to single earner households.

That is particularly the case in Melanesia, where there have been unsustainable and rapacious activities by foreign logging operators in search of quick bucks. Those have been deplorable and rightly resented. At the August meeting of the forum in Brisbane, which the honourable member mentioned, forum leaders—particularly those from Fiji, New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Vanuatu and Australia—agreed on a range of initiatives for promoting responsible and sustainable management of regional forest resources. Part of that was the development of a common code of conduct to which all companies that would be operating timber concessions in the area, logging indigenous forests, would be subject. The initiatives also include enhanced monitoring of logging and of timber exports and enhanced regional consultations.

PARA.TAB: Australia supported a range of bilateral initiatives which supplement those regional initiatives, including, importantly, an offer of a debt for nature swap in respect of the Marovo Lagoon in the Solomon Islands; other technical assistance, including a $5 1/2 million sustainable forestry project in Vanuatu; and, as far as PNG is concerned, a range of technical management assistance to successive PNG governments in that sector.

Considerable progress has already been made in implementing those forum agreed initiatives. I am pleased to say that the level of regional support for continuing that momentum is strong. In that regard, there was a very significant achievement late in October when there was a meeting in Port Vila in Vanuatu, supported by Australia, which made substantial progress on a set of guiding principles and best management practice for the proposed code of conduct. There is also a commitment to meet again before Christmas at technical level to refine those standards for the code of conduct.

In this regard I particularly applaud the actions of Vanuatu Prime Minister Maxime Carlot Korman, who has provided courageous and unequivocal support for sustainable development of the forest resources of Vanuatu, including by banning all exports of round logs and reviewing all existing licences and quotas. I believe he has discussed that most recently in Malaysia. During the meetings I had with Prime Minister Korman in Vanuatu last month, he emphasised to me the vulnerability of small Pacific island countries to unscrupulous foreign logging operators, and he expressed great appreciation for the kind of practical, direct support the Australian government was providing to Vanuatu to manage better its most valuable resource. Likewise, I wholeheartedly endorse the comments of Sir Julius Chan, the new Prime Minister of Papua New Guinea, who was reported in the Papua New Guinea Post-Courier on 1 November as saying that the intelligent and responsible use of any nation's resources is the duty of its government.

The past Solomon Islands government suspended for the third time the licence of the company involved in logging in the environmentally sensitive Marovo Lagoon area, because of the practices it was following and evidence that it was breaching the conditions of its logging agreement. A new government, as the member points out, led by the former Prime Minister Solomon Mamaloni, was elected last week by the parliament of the Solomon Islands.

We look forward to Mr Mamaloni's continuing support for sustainable development that characterised recent Solomon Islands policy. We are heartened by his press comments which drew attention to his efforts to have the Marovo Lagoon listed as a World Heritage area. We stand ready to continue to provide substantial assistance to the new government to meet its development needs in the forestry sector through human physical resources and assistance, and through the development of sustainable forestry industry practices.

I conclude by saying that it is quite vital that forestry resources in the Solomons and throughout the region bring lasting benefits to the people of the region rather than being subjected to exploitative, short-term, rapacious, destructive practices which all too often benefit offshore countries but do not benefit the people who have to live with the consequences.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is again addressed to the Minister for Transport. For a long time the Civil Aviation Authority has staggered from one disaster to another, culminating in the 7.30 Report last Thursday night which revealed that crucial safety reports were doctored by the chief executive officer and that the CAA was an unethical organisation that puts its own interests ahead of safety. —The member for Hume said that all this culminated in the 7.30 Report of last week. I do not think that that is the case. The 7.30 Report on Thursday of last week, quite frankly, itself focused very narrowly on a couple of matters in the Civil Aviation Authority—including one I have revealed to the House today, which was the subject of papers tabled in the Senate by then Senator Bishop as early as May of last year. PARA.TAB: The honourable member comes into this house and says that, if we do not act, there is likely to be a further loss of lives. This is the classic scaremonger who, I must say, would have avoided this issue like the plague in the early stage of his responsibility but who has been dragged to it by the general tactics of the opposition. TALK.START.PARA: —Today he said that, but he said that many times. I would not get too excited about that. If he had his way there would be no-one left in the Civil Aviation Authority.
