TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today with two articles about drought in my hand. One is a whole-page article from the Courier-Mail saying that the drought is the worst on record in Queensland and the other is from the Sydney Sunday Telegraph with a picture, which is familiar to everyone in Australia, of broken bones and barren, twisted land. As a nation we will see our wheat income drop from $3,000 million, which it was two or three years ago, to under $2,000 million this year—a vast collapse in the income from our sixth major export earning item. Our cattle numbers have dropped from 33 million in the late 1970s to 24 million today. Our sheep numbers have dropped from 174 million to 139 million. In fact, our agricultural production is going down at a dramatic rate.

PARA.TAB: In the midst of yet another drought, which is to many commentators the worst on record, we again have a situation where absolutely nothing has been done to arrest these problems. If it were to be a major cost and an imposition upon the rest of the Australian public to arrest these problems, then one might say there is some understanding of why we are doing nothing about the problem.

In the excellent book Work for all: full employment in the nineties, the member for Fraser (Mr Langmore) and a leading academic, John Quiggin, make the point that the real cost of unemployment in Australia is $20,000 million a year out of a budget of $115,000 million—it was probably $100,000 million when the book came out. I do not think that figure is exaggerated because it is almost identical to the figure produced by a group of Margaret Thatcher's government backbenchers in Great Britain. It is identical to the figure produced by a group which worked on the Bradfield proposals in Queensland some years ago. This group put the figure at $4,000 million on a budget of $40,000 million. That was with seven per cent unemployment, whereas the comparable figure for unemployment at present is around 16 per cent.

So I think the real cost of unemployment is such that we cannot afford not to undertake some big capital works projects in Australia. It would be hoped that we would be enlightened enough to ensure that those capital works projects result in the Australian economic cake growing in size rather than diminishing in size and that those projects be of a development nature rather than of a consumption or self-indulgent nature.

Let me move to a micro-economic analysis, if you like. If a person on a wage of $500, the average weekly earnings, paid roughly $100 tax, that would leave him with $400. If we add up what a husband, wife and two kids—the typical Australian family—get on unemployment benefits and from the housing subsidy, we end up with a figure of around $360 a week. So, clearly, the cost of paying him to work is almost the same as the cost to pay him not to work. Surely it is the height of towering stupidity to be paying one and a half million Australians not to work instead of paying them to work.

During the Great Depression in the United States, the incoming Franklin D. Roosevelt administration decided to pay people to work. During that depression, the United States built the biggest dam in the world on the Colorado River. It also built the huge Tennessee Valley Authority projects, which produce almost as much electricity as we produce in the whole of Australia—and it is produced free for ever, because it is hydro-electric power. The scheme was undertaken for irrigation and flood mitigation purposes; the hydro-electricity was just a fringe benefit that happened to be picked up on the way. That is one of the most magnificent schemes in the world.

The cost of carrying out those projects was negligible. The USA administration had to pay those people almost the same amount of money to work as it would have had to pay them not to work. In addition, the USA resuscitated, if you like, or rehabilitated 2,000 square miles of the Midwest dust bowl, as it was then referred to, with the planting of trees. The USA did all these great and wonderful things during the Great Depression, a time with high unemployment averaging around 17 per cent.

Of course, according to the book by Mr Langmore and Mr Quiggin, the real unemployment rate in Australia today is 16 per cent—almost what it was in the United States during the Great Depression. Here we are, undertaking not one single, solitary capital works project in this country of any significance to the nation whatsoever. We are paying 1.6 million Australians to sit down on their seats and do absolutely nothing. We are making exactly the same mistakes as were made in the Great Depression.

Moving on, one of the great problems in the Australian economy is the chronically high current account deficit. Every single month $2,000 million more goes out of our country than comes into it. The only way that we can finance this opprobrious situation is by using very high interest rates to keep money flowing into the country to make up for that deficit. Those high interest rates are imposing crushing burdens on people; in the last seven or eight years, we have seen 750,000 small business families in this country go broke—and that is not stopping. Queensland's Bradfield scheme and the New South Wales Clarence River diversion could add $6,000 million on our annual earnings, circuit-breaking this destructive reciprocating mechanism.

Let me switch and give the House a quick geography lesson about the northern part of Australia. My remarks apply equally to northern New South Wales and to the northern half of Queensland. On the coast we have what is called the `super wet-belt' where the annual rainfall ranges between 200 and 300 inches. This year at my office in Innisfail it rained every single day for 3 1/2 months. When I was northern development minister, a photograph was taken of me tying up a boat. I had to lean down and tie the boat up to a no-parking zone sign in the main street of Ingham. I was doing that so that I could swim over to a telephone booth to ring Richmond, 200 kilometres away, to find out whether I had to put a drought submission to cabinet on Tuesday of that week. And I had to, Mr Deputy Speaker. I had to put in a submission for an area a mere 200 kilometres away as the crow flies.

The most wonderful engineer in all of Australian history by a long way would be Dr Bradfield. He built the Sydney Harbour Bridge, the great landmark, if you like, of our greatest city in Australia; the Storey Bridge, the landmark of Brisbane, similarly; the underground railway system in Sydney; and a large proportion of all of the major dams that were built in the state of New South Wales. This wonderful Australian, out of his own money, paid engineers and surveyors to work out the flood flows and heights above sea level.

We have this huge rainfall—God has been very good to our country—of which the vast bulk falls in an area which is 2,000 feet above sea level. Then a mere 200 kilometres away is what is described and marked on the official Sunmap map of Queensland as the best natural soils and grasslands of Australia—a big flat inland plain that rolls away for 600 kilometres. You can shoot a gun in any direction and you will not hit a tree, a beast or anything. Yet these soils can be farmed for seven years, as they have been in the research projects that have been undertaken there, without the use of fertiliser. The topsoils are between six inches and 30 feet deep throughout all of that area.

We run virtually no cattle or sheep on these areas because year after year we are ravaged by drought. Officially, our rainfall is 17 inches, but in one year we had nearly 70 inches. Mr Deputy Speaker, what does that do for your average? Most of these areas are empty, bereft. They yield nothing for the planet earth. They most certainly stand as a disgrace to our nation in that we have done nothing about this situation. But these areas are only 800 feet above sea level.

Whilst we have this huge rainfall of 200 and 300 inches a year at places like Tully, Babinda, Ingham and Innisfail—where it never stops raining, quite literally—we have that rain falling above 2,000 feet and we have this magnificent plain at 800 feet. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to continue my interrupted grievance of last week on behalf of the vast number of my constituents who list crime in the community as a real concern; who daily read of the crimes perpetrated against ordinary Australians; who are appalled at the very young age of those now being charged with very serious crimes. This fear, these crimes and the involvement of the youngest of our youth are all like the muffled sounds that even an ostrich can hear when danger approaches and his ears fill up with sand. The real noise of crime in our communities would drown out all the debates in this place 10 times over.

PARA.TAB: Last week I mentioned the suburb of Rokeby in my electorate, which is situated on Hobart's eastern shore. Rokeby has 1,300 residences. In September of this year, there were 90 burglaries. At this rate, every house in the suburb will have been burgled by the time of the next federal election. Rokeby is a suburb that is so tightly in the grip of crime that front-page news was recently made when the primary school went 26 days without any incident of vandalism. This is like something out of Drop the Dead Donkey. When I started teaching in Tasmania 30 years ago, it was front-page news when a school was vandalised. Now they will stop the presses if a month goes by when a school is not attacked.

In last Saturday's Mercury, the headlines stated `God and her patrols stop school vandalism'. Even such a small step forward as this is achieved only at the cost of tremendous time, effort and expense, and after events have reached such a crescendo as to become terrifying. Rokeby Primary School's month in the sun could never have occurred without the mobilisation of the whole community after the burning of the community centre, the burning down of the school playground and the nightly patrols which followed which have been staffed by local and parents.

I would like to pay tribute to the efforts of Elaine Deeks, a woman who was described in the front page of the paper as `God'. Mrs Deeks has been an inspiration to her community. She has organised the patrols, arranged for police support and avoided the obvious dangers of vigilante action. She has faced very stiff opposition. Indeed, she has had her life threatened. Yet she stood resolute and has, with the help of her community, saved the school for 400 young children. It is rather a sad reflection of our times and somewhat of an indictment that a modern day Mary Gilmore like Elaine Deeks is not leading her community as a parliamentarian, or in local government, or by working in charitable organisations, or as an advocate for the disadvantaged in this area; rather she is forced to try to hold the line against crime. Issues of substance which affect all levels of government arise out of the experience of these individuals.

There is little to admire about the Kennett government in Victoria, especially when it comes to the provision of education health and community services. However, I admit that it has got something right in the area of recent reforms to the restrictive laws surrounding the fingerprinting of juveniles. Without boring honourable members with the details, it should be noted that the Victorian police now have the authority to fingerprint young suspects, those under 15 years, without having to seek permission from a magistrate. As a direct result of the new powers, that police force in Victoria is now solving 300 crimes a month that were otherwise unsolvable.

The second issue I want to raise is the insulation of magistrates from community values. I am often asked at Neighbourhood Watch meetings why police and legislators attend these meetings, yet the judiciary sees no cause to conduct anything so vulgar as consultation. I have to answer that I honestly do not know. Magistrates, particularly those operating in place of a jury, must be acquainted with the feelings of ordinary Australians.

There have been high profile public awareness campaigns in recent years, most notably on road safety. I think the time has come for such a campaign on home security. Statistics on the numbers of homes and cars that go unsecured daily are depressing to say the least—28 per cent of burglaries target unsecured dwellings and vehicles. Similarly, the use of personal names on gates and doorways is inviting trouble and should be discouraged as widely as possible. The cost to the community of this type of crime and the fear that it engenders are so great as to be unquantifiable.

Crime affects every one of us. This is not only in relation to our hip pockets—for example, in rising insurance premiums—but in our hearts, as the community of which we are part inches slowly but apparently unstoppably towards the law of the jungle rather than the rule of law. It affects all of us. Indeed, I believe there is not a member in this place who, if he or she genuinely examined his or her electorate, would not find in the people they represent sadness, anger, fear and frustration as a result of the crime in their community.

We are often said to be 10 years behind America in many ways. We must all hope that, as Australia approaches the next century, our cities are not swept by the crime which so plagues the cities of the United States. Not only must we hope; we must work towards this end irrespective of the various levels of government or party political affiliation. Much more urgent than the need to get government off the front page is the need to get crime off the front page of Australia's newspapers.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we approach the end of 1994—it is coming faster than we all reckoned; it will be Christmas before we know it—I want to remind the House of an event which took place nearly five years ago on 22 December 1989; that is, the unfortunate and tragic Clybucca bus smash in which 35 people lost their lives. It remains to date the most horrific and worst highway smash in Australia's history.

PARA.TAB: I want to remind the House about that because the need for special funding for the Pacific Highway still exists. An additional $300 million was supplied—$170 million from the state government and $130 million from the federal government—when the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) was Minister for Transport. Regrettably, he is no longer Minister for Transport because that funding has gone, as has the black spot funding. I want to take this opportunity to remind the House of the value of black spot funding, which was the most effective use of taxpayers' money on highways that this country has ever seen.

I want to make it quite clear, and am delighted to be able to say, that the policy of my party and on my side of politics is that black spot funding should be reinstated right around Australia. It is also our policy that the Pacific Highway should receive priority funding because this has been acknowledged by most Australians as a very great need. It is the major artery between Sydney and Brisbane—in fact it is the major traffic highway of Australia. While the Pacific Highway is not classified as a national highway, it certainly needs either that classification or the special priority funding which it deserves.

I also want to make some mention of Remembrance Day, which was celebrated right around Australia last Friday, 11 November. As we all know, the 11th hour of the 11th day of the 11th month has special significance as the time of the armistice of World War I, which was then known as the great war. I want to pay tribute to those RSL sub-branches throughout my electorate and throughout Australia which are continuing to acknowledge the sacrifice made by those who died in World War I.

In particular, I want to pay tribute to the sub-branches of the North Coast District Council of the RSL which arranged a special parade of all of those sub-branches in Coffs Harbour yesterday. In a very heart moving performance, some 500 or 600 veterans marched and participated in a memorial service. To see those men and women marching past—a great many of them limping, some in wheelchairs—was a very heart moving experience. I want to say thank you to them on behalf of my community, and indeed the Australian community, for continuing to acknowledge what was an enormous sacrifice. There were people there from the Macleay Valley, the Nambucca Valley, the Bellingen Valley, Coffs Harbour and the Clarence Valley in the electorate of Page.

Also, in the time that is available to me, I want to make some mention of the drought. I note that the first speaker in this grievance debate, the honourable member for Kennedy (Mr Katter), was outspoken, as always, about the state of the drought, particularly in North Queensland which is where his electorate is based. In northern New South Wales the drought is absolutely frightful. While we do not qualify for special assistance, there has to come a time very soon when some action is taken by the federal government to make some provision for assistance. About 93 per cent of New South Wales is declared drought stricken, but 96 per cent of New South Wales farmers will not have the opportunity of receiving any assistance at all.

In the two areas concerned with land boards—that is, Grafton and Kempsey—it will take another 10 months of drought before anybody in the Grafton area qualifies for special assistance and another 17 months in Kempsey. This just illustrates how absolutely silly the criteria are for providing assistance. I am not talking purely about social welfare assistance; there are a great many families who are not getting the help they need to put food on the table. This is not an exaggeration—I am not being dramatic or theatrical about it—it is fact.

But even more than that is the number of sheep and cattle that are being lost and the downgrading and the loss of our breeding herd. Even if we were to get drought breaking rains today, it would not solve the problem overnight. It will be years and years before we recover. I do not believe that very many people in this parliament, or throughout Australia, realise just how bad, how far-reaching and how widespread this drought is. People in my electorate are having to buy water to operate their dairies. Their creeks and dams have dried up. Every member in this place should be taking every opportunity to highlight the need for specific government assistance.

The other point I would like to make is that where fuel has been donated by oil companies and others the government should remit and forgo the fuel excise levy. Oil companies such as Shell, Ampol or Caltex provide $8,000 or $2,000 worth of fuel and the government gets half of that just in the fuel excise levy. It is certainly not appropriate.

I mentioned a moment ago the Remembrance Day commemoration. In line with that, I want to bring to the attention of the House the plight of one of my constituents, Mr Alan Thomson. He is a Vietnam veteran, lives at Coffs Harbour and receives a war pension of $70.50 per fortnight, which is a 30 per cent pension for damage to his ears from overexposure to artillery gunfire. This is basically compensation—a war pension. But, because it is deemed to be income, his unemployment benefit is reduced accordingly. He made the point in a letter to me that he has often wondered whether the bureaucrats who make these arbitrary decisions `have ever sent a good friend to his death, been shot at, mortared, or any one of a number of things that happened in that country'—South Vietnam—`that scar a man for life'.

He wants to take out a war service home loan, for which he is allegedly entitled, but he does not own a block of land. At the moment he is living in a caravan which is 25 years old and starting to decay and fall apart. It is 22 feet by eight feet and is certainly showing its age in all ways. It is probably worth about $2,000 if he could sell it. He has, more than once, made an application to take out a war service home loan to purchase a second-hand mobile home or a demountable home. He cannot buy a new one because, even if he were to get the full war service home loan, it would not be enough. He has been told that if he had a block of land on which to put it he could get the loan. But, because he does not, he cannot get it. He is condemned to spending perhaps the rest of his life in a decaying caravan. There is a need for a little more flexibility and sensitivity in the allocation of those home loans.

I also want to talk about the need for funding for the science olympiads, particularly for the Australian team. This was brought to my attention by Mr Rodd Snook of Eungai Creek. In 1992 he was the first ever gold medallist at the science olympiad. We won a gold medal in chemistry this year and came second in biology. It is quite important because the 1995 international physics olympiad will be held in Canberra and in 1998 we will host the chemistry olympiad, and we do need funding for this.
Finally, following my presenting petitions about SBS coming to the north coast, SBS must come to the north coast. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In this grievance debate I wish to address a range of strategic planning and development issues in Werriwa. The city of Campbelltown in my electorate is at a critical stage of its development. For the past 20 years it has experienced rapid population growth, placing its physical and social infrastructure under stress. That growth is now slowing. Campbelltown is maturing, meeting new challenges and opportunities.

PARA.TAB: Campbelltown City Council, to its credit, is developing a strategic plan for the city's future. In a city like Campbelltown a sense of direction is all important. Local government has a key leadership role to play, bringing together all parts of the city—community, business and state and federal governments—in support of a coherent and visionary direction for Campbelltown's development. Campbelltown council can fill the gap left by the Macarthur Development Board in urban planning and project facilitation. Its strategic plan can build on the city's many strengths. Let me just deal with three of those.

First, the city represents an interesting and challenging mix of old and new suburbs. As recently as the early 1970s, Campbelltown was a country town. It still features an old-establishment style community—the townspeople—with a strong sense of identity and civic pride but an inward looking focus. The new suburbs of Campbelltown, such as Eaglevale, Raby and St Andrews, are living out the great Australian dream: private home ownership, nurturing young families and forever seeking out new opportunities in education, sport, recreation and the arts.

Campbelltown council has developed some of the best playing fields and sporting facilities in the metropolitan area. Our young performing artists are leading the rest of Sydney. At the recent New South Wales school rock eisteddfod, for instance, three of the finalists—St Pat's, Hurlstone and Sarah Redfern High School—came from the city of Campbelltown, with Sarah Redfern winning the competition with an outstanding performance based on themes of Aboriginal reconciliation. Young people such as these provide Campbelltown with an immense pool of talent in the arts, sport, academic achievement and, for the years ahead, business and community development.

Second, as a legacy of the Macarthur Development Board, Campbelltown has a well planned and attractive green urban environment: that is, an effective separation of commercial, industrial and residential areas, well planned estates and road networks and the unique attractions of our scenic hills. No other non-coastal urban area in Australia has this kind of appeal.

Third, over the next decade Campbelltown—both for commuters and economic development—will benefit from a range of transport improvements in and around the city. These include the construction of Sydney's second international airport, an initiative of this government, at Badgerys Creek; the national highway link between the Crossroads and Hornsby, using federal road funding; a rail link between Glenfield and Badgerys Creek; the Glenfield to Ingleburn rail freight loop, now under construction as a result of One Nation; and, hopefully, rail access to Port Kembla through the completion of the Maldon-Dombarton line. The substantial transport improvements in road, rail and access to air and sea ports will enhance the Ingleburn, Minto and Campbelltown industrial estates in the development of existing industries and attraction of new companies. A pattern has emerged in the relocation of industry from older restricted sites in southern and inner Sydney to the growth area opportunities of the south-west.

For 30 years Australian planners and politicians have been talking about a new style of urban development—the model of well-planned, well-serviced suburbs with a strong correlation between the labour force, those looking for work, and the location of work. Campbelltown now has an opportunity to fulfil this model. In particular, three strategic initiatives are required. In each of them, the federal government has an important strategic role to play. The first initiative is to end the imbalance between employment and population. In 1991 Campbelltown had a labour force of 62,000 but just 25,000 jobs in its local government area. This employment retention rate of 40 per cent produces high commuter travelling times to work, placing further stress on the transport system and all of the air quality indicators.

This highlights the importance of the South-West Sydney Regional Development Organisation—I am pleased to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Housing and Regional Development, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), in the chamber—identifying competitive industry strengths and opportunities, promoting best practice initiatives, overcoming transport and planning bottlenecks, and cooperating with the three tiers of government.

Emerging industry clusters, such as the plastics group at Minto, hold immense potential for enterprise bargaining, work practice gains and the all-important export penetration. The quality of local leadership will be an important determinant of Campbelltown's economic development. Already several manufacturing companies, such as Pax Australia at Ingleburn, are leading the nation in the development of best practice methods and export growth, turning the government's programs and rhetoric into actual export achievement on the all-important Asian markets.

An opportunity exists for the federal government to play a strategic role in the services sector in generating employment. The three cities plan in the 1970s envisaged Campbelltown as a regional centre for government departments and offices. In the medium term, strong arguments will emerge for federal departments, such as Taxation and Immigration, to service the Macarthur region from major offices in Campbelltown. Sites have been identified between the Campbelltown CBD and Macarthur Square. I know my colleague the member for Macarthur (Mr Haviland) joins with me in wanting to progress the working group that has been established between this government and Campbelltown council with medium-term planning for the location of government offices and public sector jobs in the Campbelltown local government area.

Second, the city's public housing estates at Glenquarie, Minto, Airds, Claymore and Ambarvale require renewal and rejuvenation. The planning and design mistakes of the 1970s can be overcome through a range of facade improvements, streetscaping and redesign, landscaping, better use of open space and opportunities for infill development. This is a major task of urban renewal covering 5,700 public housing dwellings.

My electorate proves how the victims of poor urban design in Australia are more likely to live in suburban public housing estates than visit central business districts. State housing departments have been more interested in rental welfare and collection than capital stock rejuvenation and design issues. Happily, this is now changing. The Defence Housing Authority and a number of better cities pilot projects have established a cost-effective model for state renewal. No federal initiative would more effectively improve the quality of life and urban environment for a disadvantaged social group in Australia than entrenching these arrangements in the performance standards and funding for the 1995 Commonwealth-state housing agreement.

No initiative would more substantially upgrade the quality of life, community spirit and image of Campbelltown. Already significant progress on these plans has been achieved through the skill and cooperation of the New South Wales Housing Department, Campbelltown council and the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe). The state MPs in my electorate, Craig Knowles and Michael Knight, have also been very supportive of this initiative. I understand that it will feature prominently in the ALP's housing policy for the forthcoming New South Wales election.

Third, policies must focus on further improvements to the educational and training qualifications of Campbelltown's labour force. Large increases in school retention rates and the work of the University of Western Sydney Macarthur campus have been an inspiration to the city. Additional gains can be realised through the establishment of redistributive mechanisms in federal and state budgets for higher, vocational and school education. The availability of skilled labour is now arguably the single most important determinant of regional competitiveness. Educational agendas can be tuned to regional agendas while also addressing international competitiveness, thus becoming important instruments for economic development.

I look forward to the development of Campbelltown's strategic plan and the important role this government can play in its implementation. In a city with so much talent and commitment and the emergence of so many opportunities, this kind of strategic thinking and direction will produce enormous results. In the late 1990s and into the next decade, there is the opportunity in Campbelltown to fulfil that model of an advanced urban area.

Strategic planning is required to build on the green urban environment, well planned by the Macarthur Development Board, to close the gap between the availability of work and the size of the work force in Campbelltown and to boost those all-important educational skills. I have been a member in the area now for close to 10 months. It is a great opportunity for federal members, such as the member for Macarthur and me, to fulfil that model in the south-west of Sydney and lead the nation in aspects of employment generation, urban environment and educational standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —Over the years there have been a number of disturbing cases where the culture of the Public Service has broken down—where it has acted to protect itself rather than the public interest. I am referring to examples such as the Midford-Paramount and Voyager cases. The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) has addressed some of these long running cases; however, he has proved singularly incapable of dealing with a similar case involving his own department—the case of Mrs Sylvia Faulkner.

PARA.TAB: Mrs Faulkner is now in her 70s and in poor health. In her heyday she was a pioneer; a woman with an interest in not only heavy engineering but also running her own company. Mrs Faulkner invented a heavy lifting device, the Trisal clip, which was recognised as a major innovation with a position in the finals of the first Prince Phillip Awards. In the late 1960s, Mrs Faulkner and her husband, Reg, concentrated on developing the Trisal clip for use by the Australian Army. They had good grounds for believing that the clip would be adopted as standard army equipment and that there was considerable interest from other Allied armies. In the event, the army bought only a few dozen clips and Mrs Faulkner sued for breach of contract.

She claimed that the army's then Engineer-in-Chief, Brigadier Charles Flint, the person negotiating to buy the clip, had demanded to be made head of the Trisal company and that when she refused negotiations came to an abrupt end. Brigadier Flint was later forced to resign from the army in disgrace as a result of an investigation triggered by the complaints of Mr and Mrs Faulkner.

Mrs Faulkner went bankrupt but her breach of contract case was continued by the government appointed trustee even after her bankruptcy was discharged. But her case did not proceed normally. Delays—the bulk imposed by the defence department and government solicitors—deferred the actual trial for 13 years. Postponement is a classic tactic employed by powerful institutions to weaken opponents. For a woman who had been a millionaire, who put her whole inheritance into a brilliant invention and lost it all, 13 years was effectively a lifetime because Sylvia Faulkner's life was destroyed.

By the time her case came to court, as I said, 13 years later, her mental and physical health had been shattered by alcoholism and other major disorders. On the other side of this dispute were the Department of Defence and the Attorney-General's Department. Not surprisingly, they prevailed when Mrs Faulkner's case finally came to trial in 1987.

Recently, through an FOI request, I uncovered evidence of just how far these departments were prepared to go to shake off Mrs Faulkner and how these departments are still fighting to prevent the truth of this matter coming out. This is some of what the evidence disclosed. In December 1986, some months before the case was heard, the Attorney-General, Lionel Bowen, agreed to offer the Faulkners a $100,000 settlement plus their costs if this offer was accepted within two weeks. But the offer was vetoed by the defence department. So, instead of an offer, Mr Bowen approved a review of the legal funding Sylvia Faulkner received as a bankrupt and which she needed to conduct her case.

The review was conducted by the Commonwealth Solicitor-General, Dr Gavan Griffith. Dr Griffith was to find out what chance Mrs Faulkner had of winning her case so that he could recommend whether aid should continue. There are a number of concerns about this review, foremost of which is Dr Griffith's obvious conflict of interest. Even then secretary to the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Pat Brazil, in his submission to Mr Bowen of 9 December 1986 outlining options for the case, conceded this conflict. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is fair to assume that there will be criticism if the review is undertaken . . . and that criticism will increase greatly if, as a result of it, financial assistance is terminated. It could be said that the Solicitor-General, who is the main advocate of the first defendant (the Commonwealth), would in effect be deciding the merits of the claim brought against the Commonwealth.

Another concern was the linking of settlement to a possible withdrawal of financial assistance. Records indicate that Mr Jack Hiatt, the Commonwealth's senior barrister, described this as `akin to blackmail'. A third concern was the advice given to Dr Griffith by the barrister acting for Mrs Faulkner, Mr Greg Woods QC. According to previous advice from Mr Woods, the testimony of overseas witnesses was vital to Mrs Faulkner's case, so funding restrictions meant she could not win. However, in his submission to Dr Griffith on 24 February 1987, Mr Woods changed his mind about the witnesses. He divided the case into two separate sections and declared:
The first part of the claim will, in my view undoubtedly succeed with very substantial damages. The second is hazardous and involves certain difficulties of proof.

Mr Woods then claimed that it was only the second part of the case relating to the loss of patent on the Trisal Clip which needed the overseas and interstate witnesses. When Dr Griffith called a meeting with Mrs Faulkner's lawyers in March 1987, all were turned away except Mr Woods. The other lawyers were upset, but they had no say. Subsequently, Dr Griffith concluded that Mrs Faulkner did have reasonable prospects of success but strictly limited her legal funding. She was to be allowed no overseas witnesses and only two interstate witnesses. The hearing would be restricted to 15 days. Every lawyer who had reviewed Mrs Faulkner's case believed she had reasonable prospects of success, yet the Government Solicitor's Office in Sydney, representing the Department of Defence, was adamant that her case was `baseless and without merit' and a `try-on'.

PARA.TAB: Prior to the trial, a senior Defence official wrote to the Attorney-General's Department outlining why he believed Mrs Faulkner's claim was absurd. He claimed that Mrs Faulkner would be unable to prove a causal connection between Flint's alleged misrepresentations and any loss, that she would be unable to substantiate that moneys were advanced to the companies in question, that she did not have the proprietary interests in the companies and the patent rights to the Trisal Clips that she claimed, that no marketing opportunities were lost because the clip was unmarketable and that companies could not manufacture them in marketable quantities, and that the credibility of Mr and Mrs Faulkner was questionable. As far as we know without a full transcript of Mrs Faulkner's case, these claims were not raised in court. What we do know from the judgment is that the judge believed none of these claims to be true except the last relating to the Faulkners' credibility.

The Commonwealth maintained that Brigadier Flint had written certain letters and made certain statements that implied the clip would be purchased but that the letters had really been co-authored by Reg Faulkner in collusion with Brigadier Flint. Flint was Defence's key witness. Defence had tried to disown him, to pin all the blame on him and to make him pay his own costs. After all, he had been drummed out of the army in disgrace.

But it was forced to change its tune on 26 February 1987 when the Defence Force Ombudsman ruled decisively that Flint was entitled to have his costs paid by the Commonwealth. Indeed, Flint's initial submission to the ombudsman, which recently came into my possession, indicated that the defence department had plenty to worry about. In it, Flint stated that he did tell Trisal—that is, the Faulkners—that the army was going to buy the clip and that procedures for its introduction were initiated but that there were unavoidable delays.

Brigadier Flint also said that his own dealings with Trisal were on behalf of the Commonwealth. This constitutes significant new evidence. That was Flint's position in 1975, but Flint's financial position was precarious and Defence was threatening his pension. In February 1987, a senior official in the Attorney-General's Department legal services, Mr Peter Swinton, jotted notes of an extraordinary meeting with the Commonwealth's senior barrister, Mr Jack Hiatt QC, at which Mr Hiatt had said that Swinton should contact Defence and say:

SPEECH.PARA: Flint has run the gamut of departmental proceedings and ought not now to have his pension affected—if that is the departmental position, let's confirm that and inform Flint. Flint should be required to say he acted without authority.

The possibility was thus raised that Flint's evidence would be influenced—that the Commonwealth, through its officials, would hold Flint to ransom. One week later, on 11 February 1987, Mr Swinton spoke with Mr Robert Muecke in the litigation section of the Attorney-General's Department. His file note contains the comment:

re Flint proposal: he thought it sounded like we were trying to buy evidence, even if it was the truth. I said where's the ethical problem in buying truth? He said he thought truth will out in cross-examining Flint as adversary in any event.

Here we have it in writing: the Commonwealth lawyers were planning to buy evidence. But given the distorted view of the facts held by the defence department, which was briefing the lawyers, we must wonder whether truth was bought. The government had also been seeking an indemnity from Flint to protect itself from a cross-claim from Flint if he lost his part of the case in which he was co-defendant. Did Flint give some indemnity and, if so, was his pension used as leverage?

PARA.TAB: On 2 April 1987, a few weeks before the hearing, Pat Brazil wrote to the Attorney-General's Department saying that, depending on the advice from the Commonwealth's lawyers on the prospects of success and the part Flint might play in proceedings, `we may need to look again at the questions of a possible settlement and payment of Flint's costs'. Was it because it was now certain that Flint's evidence would be favourable and that Mrs Faulkner would be unable to call crucial witnesses that the Government Solicitor's, the Attorney-General's and the defence departments decided not to settle?

One feature of this case has been the disappearance of important documents. Most of the transcript of the court case has gone missing from the New South Wales Supreme Court Registry. One official claimed cryptically that the `white cockies' must have got at it.

Even now, the Attorney-General's Department finds it is hard to part with some documents on its files. The FOI request was lodged at the end of January 1984. The Australian Government Solicitor's Office promised the documents by the end of March. A month after expiry of the processing period, my office appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the grounds of deemed refusal. On 11 May, the AGS notified its decision on the documents. At a directions hearing on 16 May 1994 it claimed that it had been very generous in its decision on the release of documents. It was nevertheless decided to ask the AAT to rule on the documents remaining in dispute. In August, the AGS forwarded material it considered non-contentious. AGS also gratuitously forwarded the New South Wales court judgment. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to deal with a recent campaign by quite a lot of people in Australia for citizens initiated referenda. I do not totally support what these people have been doing and I have not been able to endorse their campaign; nevertheless, I can see some validity in their proposition that the people of Australia do not feel sovereign, that people feel they do not have any input into decisions.

PARA.TAB: While people can take quite effective action by seeing their local member of parliament, there is not time to deal with all problems all people have. People simply do not come to members of parliament often because they do not realise just how they can be helped.

Members of parliament certainly have a lot of successes, but there are 70,000 voters for each federal member of parliament. You then take out time for parliament and its committees, which would be at least 100 days a year. You also take out time for functions and delegations and perhaps the occasional Sunday off or a vacation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha!

—The honourable member for Forde obviously does not have much time to do that. Neither do I, but 160 days would be cut out for those purposes—functions, delegations and vacations. That leaves about 100 days. If we spent 14 hours a day talking to our local constituents, we would be giving one minute and 14 seconds per voter.

PARA.TAB: Most of us know that there are people we never see and there are others we see a lot of in our general work within the electorate office. So there are a lot of people out there who feel that there is no line for input into government decisions. I commend the people, whatever their political persuasion, for coming up with the suggestion of citizens initiated referenda because it is an attempt to deal with that problem.

The proposition I am coming up with is one which does not involve petitions but actually involves citizens who want to make a change in going to a set place over a set period and registering their request for action by a level of government in the way that the citizens initiated referenda would do. I certainly do not see as democratic or legitimate people being asked on street corners to sign petitions, or people going around to houses to have petitions signed. It is too easy to get rid of someone by saying, `Yes, I'll sign it.' That does not work well for good government.

It is interesting to look around our electorates at some of the successes people have had in getting small local community groups together. There are not very many of them. For instance, in Queanbeyan there is one particular Neighbourhood Watch group which seems to get 30 to 40 people from that very small local precinct area at every one of its meetings. That is a very high proportion of the people who live in the area. They get together and talk about local security, but this naturally leads to other issues, some of which relate to work being done by levels of government.

I want to briefly show how the need for people to feel sovereign, to feel as though they have democratic rights and to feel as though they can have an input to decisions can be incorporated into a proposal, which I have mentioned in two or three motions to this parliament and which have been supported by members in the parliament, to substantially reform local government and to reduce the number of levels of government to two.

There are people in North Queensland, in Northern Australia, in Central Australia, in north-western Victoria and south-western New South Wales who see themselves as separate from, say, Melbourne and Sydney respectively. There are people in the Australian Capital Territory and south-eastern New South Wales who see themselves as living in one region. It is interesting that the recent proposal by the Minister for Housing and Regional Development (Mr Howe), which has come to him from the state and territory governments, incorporates both the ACT and south-eastern New South Wales into one region.

That proposal gives us a foundation upon which we can build so that we can have much more successful and much more answerable local government. I believe that the people in each local area ought to be able to appoint representatives to local town meetings. Small areas of towns and small local villages ought to be able to have precinct meetings and report to local town meetings, and those town meetings should be able to relate to government. I firmly believe that it is well worth considering the proposition of the President of the Australian Local Government Association, Peter Woods, that we ought to have about 80 local council governments.

TALK.START.PARA: —He's gone; they gave him the sack.

—Yes, I know, I should have said the former member. I also believe we should consider the proposition that has been endorsed by Sir Ninian Stephen that we ought to have two levels of government. Even the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) said that it might have been better if we had started with only two levels. But we started with three and, according to him, we have to live with it.

PARA.TAB: I believe we do not have to live with it and that we will not live with it into the next century because people are changing and are getting a bit sick of the system they see now, including the party system. One good way of changing that would be by giving people more local power. The suggestion, in the case of the Commonwealth government, of 31 regions for regional economic development is proving to be very popular in a lot of local areas, particularly those that are interested in taking a regional approach to tourism or a regional approach to building up businesses.

Recently, I took a group of people from travel bureaus around the world to the electorate of Eden-Monaro and showed them a number of the attractions of the electorate—and I will be showing them more a little later on. They have had a look at the south-east coast. They are going to have a look at the Snowy Mountains. They are delighted with what they have seen and they can come up with packages that embrace a region. In the case of this region, you can include the ACT with a lot of attractions in south-eastern New South Wales.

It is working. I believe the REDO approach—the regional economic development organisation approach—is showing that it can work already. Whether we had 80 local council governments, as suggested by Peter Woods, or 31, which is the federal approach, either of those would be successful and would be a much more effective local government structure. Of course, that local government structure could go in two directions. First of a all, it would be elected by the people.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments put by the coalition in the Main Committee have been fully debated in that committee and I would just like to add one or two comments on aspects of the Australian Postal Corporation Amendment Bill with which the coalition is less than satisfied. The first matter is the issue of the frequency of roadside delivery services. This was referred to by the Industry Commission in its report on the efficiency of the mail, courier and parcel services industries. The commission recommended that, in those areas where roadside delivery is made only once a week, frequency be increased to twice a week.

PARA.TAB: The coalition has long been of the view that a twice-weekly service should be available to rural and regional Australians. In the regional communications policy, which we took to the last election, we made a commitment to increase the government's maximum once weekly service to a minimum twice weekly service. Despite the government's hollow boasts in the 1994 edition of The Rural Book that every effort was being made to provide at least two services a week to those in rural areas, including the most remote areas, this bill shows no evidence of any such efforts.

The Industry Commission's recommendation has simply been ignored in the fashion typical of the government's neglect of rural and remote Australia. The coalition has attempted to hold the government to its empty promises through its proposed amendment to clause 8 of the bill and will continue to remind the government of its unfulfilled obligation in this regard.

The second matter which has caused concern not only to the coalition but also to post office agents and licensees is clause 17 of the bill, which excludes post office agents and licensees from offering any discounts on Australia Post products. Australia Post itself, through post offices run by the corporation, effectively offers discounts by allowing bulk mail and advertising discounts. Post office agents and licensees are not allowed to offer such discounts to their customers. I have received representations from the Post Office Agents Association protesting this distinction and have been receiving faxes all morning from agents and licensees calling for an end to this distinction.

The rationale behind this decision is apparently that it has been claimed by Australia Post that some postal agents and licensees have been selling stamps to customers at discounted prices. However, it has been acknowledged by Australia Post that it is not a large problem. The bill allows the corporation to obtain a Federal Court injunction against an agent or licensee where there is evidence of discounting. Such draconian measures do not seem warranted by what Australia Post and the agents and licensees see as being a minor problem. The major issue which remains unresolved under this bill is the advantage which the corporation will have over the smaller agents and licensees.

Clause 26 as it stands allows the minister to dismiss any member of the board of Australia Post. Such a degree of ministerial control over the board and the possibility of interference in, and intimidation of, the board by the minister cannot go unremarked. The coalition has spoken in the strongest possible terms against this provision.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I will just make it clear, as the shadow minister for employment, training and family services, the honourable member for Goldstein (Dr Kemp) has pointed out, that this debate was the subject of quite extensive discussion in the Main Committee. There has been a deal of discussion around these issues. I want to make it clear that the government does not accept the amendments proposed by the opposition.

PARA.TAB: Following that debate, a confused position has arisen as to the opposition's view about Australia Post. On the one hand, we are being lectured because we have not more rigorously followed the Industry Commission report on the deregulation of postal services; yet, at the same time, the attempt to prescribe two mail deliveries per week to all areas is still part of the opposition agenda, notwithstanding the fact that the fundamental thrust of the debate was all about deregulation and, essentially, the privatisation of Australia Post services, et cetera.

We make it clear that we are determined to ensure that the efficiencies of Australia Post are maximised and that the very strong improvement that has been achieved in Australia Post in recent years is continued. Under the arrangements that the bill provides, around 50 per cent of Australia Post's revenue is now being opened up to competition. We think that is a very positive step in ensuring that the efficiency and productivity of Australia Post are continued and advanced. But nothing in the opposition's amendments will add to that cause.

Indeed, nothing in the opposition's amendments resolve the problem of areas which at the moment do not receive the once a week service. Indeed, the likelihood is that the further marginalisation of aspects of Australia Post's services to remote areas will be curtailed by that approach. For those reasons, and given that the debate in the Main Committee has been quite extensive, the government is opposed to the amendments outlined by the opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to clause 12 which the coalition has proposed do not seek to make any radical changes to the existing legislation. The coalition seeks to maintain the status quo with regard to document exchange services. Amendment No. 2 put by the coalition in the Main Committee seeks only to ensure that document exchange services can continue to provide to their customers an end-to-end service.

PARA.TAB: Australia's biggest document exchange service, Ausdoc, has expressed concerns that the bill as it stands will reduce its ability to provide its current level of service. The government's proposed prohibition on carrying documents from one document exchange service to another or on direct delivery to the address of individual members will only serve as an impediment to efficient business practices.

The definition of `organisation' in clause 12 also gives rise to some concern that current practices will be limited. Government departments and subsidiaries of the same company will not be able to have a private contractor carry their mail from office to office. The definition which the government has proposed is excessively narrow and will mean that many business and community groups will not have a choice as to who may carry their mail from office to office.

The proposed amendment to clause 15 of the bill, which allows Australia Post to negotiate with customers agreed terms and conditions for the supply of a bulk interconnection service, including discounts for mail carried by private operators to designated mail centres, seeks only to ensure that discounts for bulk interconnection services will apply intrastate as well as interstate. As it stands, the bill makes no distinction, but concerns have been raised by the Prices Surveillance Authority that discounts for bulk interconnection will only apply where mail has been transported interstate by private operators.

It is regrettable that the amendments proposed by the coalition and supported by the recommendations of not only the Industry Commission but also the Prices Surveillance Authority, the major mail users of Australia and the Post Office Agents Association have been dismissed by the government to the detriment of consumers of postal services. I take this opportunity to exhort the government to reconsider its stance on these amendments in light of the concerns which have been raised in the Senate and the Main Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again I will mention that these issues have been well and truly canvassed up to this point. I made a point earlier in the debate that we have taken significant steps towards the commercialisation of a range of Australia Post activities. TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly a pleasure to be speaking on this piece of legislation in continuation from the sitting of the parliament last week. The legislation before the parliament, including the amendment moved by the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), is the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994. The House will recall that the erstwhile Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton), after much toing-and-froing from the ACTU during 1993, introduced the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill 1993. This is a continuation of more amendments to that legislation. The minister is certainly subject to a fair bit of arm twisting by the members of the United Mineworkers Federation.

PARA.TAB: The amendment moved by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong, states:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) admonishes the Minister for Industrial Relations for clearly failing to meet his April 1994 promise to fully absorb coal industry arrangements into the industrial relations mainstream;
(2) condemns the Government's continued preference to satisfy the narrow sectional interests of trade union leaders rather than govern in the national interest; and

(3) deplores the erratic fashion in which the Minister for Industrial Relations manages his portfolio responsibilities, clearly exemplified by the number of different bills presented by the Minister on the subject of the coal industry".

We will talk a little more a bit later about some of those public comments and commitments, going back to April this year, that were made by the Minister for Industrial Relations with regard to what he saw as the correct response to dealing with the Coal Industry Tribunal. That response was to abolish it altogether and absorb its activities clearly into the mainstream industrial relations system in Australia. He has not done that. Once again, he is sitting on top of the organ and acting like the monkey.

PARA.TAB: The coalition opposes specialist industrial tribunals. Employers, including the New South Wales Coal Association, have been calling for the coal industry to be brought into the mainstream for 10 years. The Hancock inquiry way back in 1985 called for the Coal Industry Tribunal to be abolished and for that industry to be brought into mainstream industrial relations in Australia. To date it has not happened. This bill will not make it happen. The minister fails miserably to address what has been called for by all sections of the industry, apart from his mates in the United Mineworkers Federation, for in excess of a decade. We will come to the $200,000 worth of reasons for this a little later on.

The purpose of this bill is to provide for a two-stage transfer of the functions of the Coal Industry Tribunal, the CIT, to the Australian Industrial Relations Commission and the abolition of the CIT following the transfer of all its functions. The bill will also increase the salaries payable to members of parliament, although we know that this is just a change in the description of payments.

The CIT was established by the Commonwealth and New South Wales coal industry acts of 1946. So it is fairly anachronistic. The CIT, along with the Joint Coal Board, was established to facilitate settlement of disputes in the volatile coal industry and to allow greater government influence in the New South Wales coal industry. It followed a campaign by the mineworkers federation to establish government control of mines. The situation after the war was of a finely balanced supply and demand for coal so that even a minor disruption in the supply of coal had an effect on industry and domestic users of coal. It was also a time of change in the industry with increasing mechanisation and calls for nationalisation of the industry.

While the need for a separate industrial tribunal for the coal industry has been called into question a number of times during the CIT's existence—for example, the Hancock committee in its 1985 report entitled Australian industrial relations law and systems recommended the CIT's absolute abolition, and the Hancock committee certainly did not fall down on our side of politics; it was supported by the government—the current proposal to place industrial relations in the coal industry within the mainstream industrial relations system arose from a strike by miners over coal prices in April 1994. In response to the strike and the inability of the CIT to quickly resolve the dispute, the Minister for Industrial Relations announced his intention to abolish the CIT and place the coal industry within the ambit of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The decision was based on the miners' contempt for decisions of the CIT and the hope that miners would show more respect for the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. That in itself is probably a little bit of a joke.

Let us look at what the minister had to say in April this year during that strike. He was going to completely abolish the Coal Industry Tribunal because it was not doing its job. He wanted to bring the coal unions and the mining unions into the mainstream industrial relations system in Australia. In an interview that the minister did with Monica Attard, Ms Attard said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government has announced it will abolish the Coal Industry Tribunal, as coal workers across the country strike. Industrial Relations Minister, Laurie Brereton, has criticised the United Mineworkers' Union for continually ignoring the rulings of the tribunal in their protest over discount coal prices to Japanese buyers. Mr Brereton told reporters in Canberra a short time ago, that because of the union's continued contempt of the tribunal, he'll move to bring the coal workers under the auspices of the Industrial Relations Commission.
The minister said:

Let me say today that I believe and the Government believes that the decision of the Mineworkers' Union to take industrial action each time they're dissatisfied with the outcome of coal price negotiations, is a totally unsatisfactory state of affairs. It's doing great damage to this industry, and from the Government's point of view it is totally unacceptable.
He went on to say:

I think it's high time that, given the contempt that the union has consistently shown for decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal, that we should bring the coal industry into the mainstream of industrial relations and bring it under the auspices of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and I'll be taking steps to put that into effect. Are there any questions?
The reporter said:
That tribunal was set up 1949; it's long since outlived its usefulness. Do you think that you will have any trouble in moving it back into the Industrial Relations Commission?
The minister said:

Well, let me say, it's been there for a long time and I think it's done a very good job in many respects, but it's equally clear, as a result of the course of action of the Mineworkers' Union over recent months, that the union is not prepared to take any notice of it at all and its orders. And it's against that background that I think it's appropriate that it should be brought within the mainstream of industrial relations in Australia, and that is the Industrial Relations Commission.
There you have it. The minister went on to say:

Well, I would hope that all Australians would support the idea of an industrial umpire that covers all industry, and I would think that it's entirely reasonable in these circumstances that the commission responsible for almost every area of IR in Australia should have an overview of the coal industry, and that's what I'll be proposing.

But has that happened? Certainly not. What has happened is that the Coal Industry Tribunal has been brought under the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, but it has its own separate little entity within that organisation. It comes under the umbrella of the Industrial Relations Commission, but it is a little bit autonomous in its own right. That was a fob off to the mineworkers union and Mr Maitland, who has put an enormous amount of pressure on the minister in this regard.

PARA.TAB: The coalition is opposed to the moves that the government is making in this regard. We believe that we should be completely abolishing the CIT and that we should not be bringing it under the umbrella of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It should be done away with completely. If we are going to have an industrial relations mechanism in Australia, it should be for everybody in the workplace. We need one set of rules and one umpire—not one umpire for one set of people and a different umpire for another set of people. The shadow minister has moved his amendment along those lines.

It is interesting to read a letter that was circulated by Mr Peter Barrack from the Newcastle Trades Hall Council. This letter concerns this minister and his actions in a number of his portfolio areas. He has not become very popular within his own constituency. Mr Barrack's letter reads:

SPEECH.PARA: We must again, in the strongest terms and out of due concern for the credibility of the Labor Government, protest against the retention of Laurie Brereton as Minister for Industrial Relations and Transport.
To mention the Ministers name in any forum of working people and Labour supporters is to bring howls of derision, anger and outbursts of obscenities against him.

Have members of the Government forgotten that because of Minister Brereton's widespread unpopularity, even Barrie Unsworth had to remove him from positions of prominence as he was considered an electoral liability?
In the Hunter region it is argued forcibly that Laurie was indirectly responsible for the loss of the two safest seats in New South Wales ie. Swansea and Newcastle in the 1987 NSW elections.

The Government should be warned that while Laurie Brereton remains Minister for Industrial Relations it will not be possible to mobilise the level of rank and file involvement in the electoral process that was achieved in 1993—

Maitland reminds the meeting how he personally handed over the union's $200,000 donation to the ALP before the last Federal election . . .

That is what this is all about. At the beginning of last year the minister was going to introduce all sorts of reforms in the industrial relations area of his portfolio concerning enterprise bargaining, voluntary unionism and unfair dismissal. At the beginning of 1994, he made public promises about abolishing the Coal Industry Tribunal, because it was not being taken notice of by the unions. He was going to move the coal industry within the ambit of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. What has happened? He has failed miserably. Why? PARA.TAB: Let us look at the chronology of what has happened this year with this bill. I will start with the development of the bill. On 19 April 1994, Brereton pledged to abolish the Coal Industry Tribunal and to absorb its functions into the industrial relations mainstream under the auspices of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I beg your pardon. In July 1994 the minister released weak exposure draft legislation which was obviously drafted with the United Mineworkers Federation in mind. The exposure draft had two stages, each to commence on proclamation. Stage 1 was to introduce a right of appeal to the commission of CIT decisions. PARA.TAB: In August 1994 the United Mineworkers Federation released a response to the exposure draft legislation. It totally rejected absorption. It specifically rejected all the major facets of the draft. It called for the tribunal to work autonomously within the commission. The response submitted that appeals to the full bench should take place only when precedent had not been set within the CIT. This effectively precluded appeals to the full bench of the commission because the CIT had set so many since its creation in 1946.

In October 1994 the Industrial Relations Amendment Bill (No. 2) was introduced into the House. The bill set out two stages in a similar form to the draft exposure. However, a minimum period of two years was set for stage 1, deferring stage 2 to the next parliament and to the next industrial relations minister. What was stage 2? It was the abolition and the absorption of the CIT into the mainstream industrial relations system in Australia. Also, the minister promised a tripartite body to review the need for abolition during the minimum two-year stage 1 period. This appeared to be a poorly thought out idea to placate the caucus. It was unclear how it would operate and did not appear in the bill. The central council of the united mineworkers gave its president, John Maitland, the power to call an indefinite coal strike if meetings with the minister and the ACTU president failed. Maitland told reporters:

SPEECH.PARA: Laurie appears to me to be the type of person that likes to engage in a bit of brinkmanship, and I'm now in a position to engage in the same sort of brinkmanship.

That is the attitude of Mr John Maitland, the President of the United Mineworkers Federation. On 13 October there was a caucus economic and industrial relations committee meeting followed by a private meeting between the minister, Mr Maitland, Mr Ferguson and caucus committee chairman, the honourable member for Lilley (Mr Swan). Mr Maitland said that the threat of a national coal strike was on hold pending discussions in the following week. PARA.TAB: On 19 October newspapers reported that the minister would amend the bill to implement the union's demands. The Australian Coal Association wrote to the minister, with signatures of 20 leading coal body and company heads, to strongly oppose watering down of the bill. The minister wrote to the Australian Coal Association chairman, calling reports that he has acquiesced to union demands `pure speculation'. Australian Bureau of Statistics figures reported that working days lost in the coal mining industry increased from 69,900 in the 12 months ended July 1993 to 171,700 in the 12 months ended July 1994—an increase of 146 per cent. On 20 October the Secretary of the Newcastle Trades Hall Council, Mr Peter Barrack, wrote to ALP colleagues calling for the minister's sacking as the industrial relations minister.

On 7 November the bill was introduced, and here we are now debating it. So where has it come from? It has come from the United Mineworkers Federation. It is the same old story. We are seeing the same actions that we saw last year. The minister is not in control of this portfolio. The government is not in control of this portfolio; the ACTU is in control of this portfolio, as was evidenced last year when the Industrial Relations Bill was introduced and finally passed through this parliament at the end of last year just before Christmas. It resembled absolutely nothing like that which was promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the then Minister for Industrial Relations at the March 1993 election. It did not even resemble the promises that they made to the people of Australia as to what they were going to do in the area of industrial relations in this term of the parliament, if re-elected.

Again, in this bill we see the union movement playing the organ; the minister is the monkey on top of the organ doing the dance. How many times are we going to see this minister backing down, having his arm twisted by the union movement and having the union movement completely rewriting the industrial relations law to suit the government? We no longer have a system that treats everybody equally. The Labor Party in government has berated the opposition. It has bored the Australian public witless about discrimination on all sorts of fronts. When it comes to industrial relations, it is the greatest perpetrator of discrimination this country has ever seen. People in this country no longer have the right to make the decision as to whether or not they belong to a union. They no longer have the right to say that they want to employ a non-union worker. People cannot do those things as a result of the actions of the Minister for Industrial Relations, overseen by the Prime Minister and the people who have hold of the levers—the ACTU.
