TALK.START.PARA: —I endorse totally what my colleague the member for Lyne (Mr Vaile) said just a few minutes ago. If anyone needed any evidence that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) was unfit to hold office, that evidence is contained in the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1994 and all of the machinations that have taken place between this government and the union movement along the long and tortuous road to debating this bill in the parliament.

PARA.TAB: The bill seeks to amend legislation in a number of areas. It claims to bring the coal industry into the mainstream industrial relations system and to allow for the eventual abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal, and it deals with a couple of other aspects of governmental activity. I intend to concentrate on the question of the Coal Industry Tribunal. The reality is that, given the minister's having made a promise a number of months ago and having reneged from being battered by the union movement, the legislation which we are now debating means that the minister has delivered to the unions two of their central demands. In effect, a new specialist coal panel will be created within the commission, rather than the Coal Industry Tribunal being totally absorbed into the commission. Also, and most seriously, the commission will have to take tribunal decisions into account when dealing with coal matters. In April this year the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the contempt that the union has consistently shown for decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal, that we should bring the coal industry into the mainstream of industrial relations and bring it under the auspices of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, and I'll be taking steps to put that into effect.
He went on to say:

I would hope that all Australians would support the idea of an industrial umpire that covers all industry, and I would think that it is entirely reasonable in these circumstances that the commission responsible for almost every other area of industrial relations in Australia should have an overview of the coal industry, and that's what I'll be proposing.

The reality is that in April this year the minister promised reform which the opposition would have supported. We have supported for a long time the total abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal because of its shocking record in this area. The minister and the government obviously sought to adopt our policy. But what has happened? The minister and his mates had a meeting, then another meeting, and we find that he has dragged into the public arena a multiplicity of proposals. He is rolled time and time again by Maitland and union troglodytes. Instead of an umpire that covers all industries—namely, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission—the minister now wants to maintain a de facto specialist coal tribunal. He wants special courts for special people. When we look at what the government proposes—and given the history of Minister Brereton and his mates of making deals—we find that he wants special deals for special people.

PARA.TAB: The people of Australia have had a gut full of the way this government operates. If we are going to have a system that is seen to be accountable, seen to be open and seen to be fair and doing the job, what is wrong with bringing the coal industry into the area of industrial conciliation and arbitration which exists for almost every other industry in Australia? The minister obviously does not want this to happen—or if he wanted it to happen then the union bosses did not. It is absolutely disgusting that the minister is dancing to the union's tune.

The union has objected strongly to what the minister and government tried to do. My colleague referred to the letter which Peter Barrack circulated to his ALP colleagues in which he set out in very clear, compelling and obvious ways that the union movement had no confidence in Minister Brereton. We have no confidence either in Minister Brereton. In my view, he is the most utterly incompetent industrial relations minister this country has ever had.

On the one hand, he promises that the Coal Industry Tribunal will be totally abolished and that the coal industry will be dealt with, as other industries are, in the Industrial Relations Commission but, on the other hand, this bill seeks to implement a provision that the Coal Industry Tribunal be allowed to continue to exist by another name. It is a Clayton's change. The Coal Industry Tribunal is being brought in as a specialist section of the commission and it will continue to have an existence of its own.

The government might say that, given the shocking record of the Coal Industry Tribunal, while it will exist as a section of the Industrial Relations Commission, new rules will apply; the same rules that apply to the commission in other areas will apply to the Coal Industry Tribunal; and the Coal Industry Tribunal's bad record will be wiped out and we might have some decent decisions in the future. But, no, the government says that the decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal must in future be used as precedents.

Let us look at some decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal. In 1983, three pit ponies were still being used in an underground mine. The union objected to proposals to retire the horses. Mr Deputy Speaker, can you believe this? A decision was formally notified in 1986 and the union's position was upheld. The horses were retired only when the union consented in 1989 and after three years of very inconclusive inspections and hearings. I suppose the horses were just about to collapse of old age. That is the kind of decision that the Industrial Relations Commission will have to take into account when dealing with coal industry matters.

In another classic case a company decided to retrench 140 employees because it had a mine that could not make a profit. The local coal authority interpreted a site agreement to mean that it could not retrench those employees unless less senior employees at a nearby better performing mine were retrenched first. Everyone went out on strike. What happened? Some 280 workers lost their jobs, not 140 workers. That again was endorsed by the Coal Industry Tribunal. Those kinds of crazy, mad and insane arrangements are now to be incorporated by the commission in its deliberations on the coal industry.

I will give another example. A dispute arose between a company and two unions over whether crane drivers or tradesmen should operate a small lifting device attached to a maintenance truck. The dispute led to an order by the local coal authority that tradesmen should operate the device when lifting equipment on or off the vehicle, but a crane driver had to be called in if the device was used to hold parts in position while they worked on them. This is absolute certifiable madness. That kind of principle is to be followed by the commission when it deals with coalmining matters in the future.

Another widely publicised example given by the New South Wales Coal Association is that in 1993 the United Mineworkers Federation sought enforcement of an alleged industry practice of recruitment only from union retrenchment lists. The union threatened national industrial strife if it could not maintain its closed shop and provide the list of employees available to a mine. The Coal Industry Tribunal found that custom and practice at the mine was recruitment from the retrenchment list—nothing about the best person for the job—and that the practice was reasonable and ordered it to continue. Furthermore, the industry suffers from roster arrangements that are inflexible; overmanning and absenteeism remain a serious problem.

This is the catastrophic state of affairs over which the Coal Industry Tribunal has presided. These are the reasons why Minister Brereton said earlier this year that the Coal Industry Tribunal had to go. But the government's response is to allow this dinosaur to continue under another name as part of the Industrial Relations Commission. I think that is quite disgusting.

This government has a Minister for Industrial Relations who is totally inept. We have only to look at the minister's history when he was a minister in New South Wales. We all remember the problems with the Sydney Harbour Tunnel and the billions of dollars of New South Wales taxpayers that were lost through special deals that the minister did with some people in New South Wales. We also know what a menace the minister is to air safety in Australia. He goes skiing at Thredbo while planes are falling out of the sky. He is completely dilatory in his approach to his duties.

PARA.TAB: I think the people of Australia deserve better. It is about time that we had in this country a minister who is prepared to act on what he says. The regard that people have for politicians in this country has never been lower. The minister marched into the industrial relations arena earlier this year and said that he was going to make a very necessary and required amendment. Yet, after the attacks made on the minister by Maitland from the United Mineworkers Federation and Barrack, we find that again he has changed his story.

The member for Lyne has outlined how the minister has failed to deliver. The minister has in effect been very hard to pin down. Every time he made a public utterance the utterance changed, with the result that we are now debating this bill, which does not bring about a change that is desperately needed. It does not make a reform which is absolutely essential. It entrenches the bad industrial relations practices which have been allowed to grow up in the coal industry over the years into the new tribunal.

The Coal Industry Tribunal is not being abolished; it is simply being made a part of the Industrial Relations Commission. Further, the Industrial Relations Commission is required to take note, and therefore implement, the precedent decisions by the Coal Industry Tribunal. So this minister stands condemned. That is why I am particularly pleased to participate in this debate. I am honoured to support the amendment moved by my colleague the honourable member for Bennelong, which states in part:
That all words after `That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: `whilst not opposing the passage of this Bill, the House:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) admonishes the Minister for Industrial Relations for clearly failing to meet his April 1994 promise to fully absorb coal industry arrangements into the industrial relations mainstream;

Clearly the minister has failed to do that. He said that he would but he has failed to do it. It is right that this chamber should admonish the minister for his incompetence and for being, in effect, totally inefficient. Further, the amendment:
(2) condemns the Government's continued preference to satisfy the narrow sectional interests of trade union leaders rather than govern in the national interest;

The minister announced his preferred option. He was immediately attacked by the mineworkers and by others associated with the industry with the result that yet again he has rolled over, failed to deliver, and failed the Australian people. Further, the amendment:

(3) deplores the erratic fashion in which the Minister for Industrial Relations manages his portfolio responsibilities, clearly exemplified by the number of different bills presented by the Minister on the subject of the coal industry'.

Therefore, we have a minister who apparently has told colleagues that he wants to be rid of the industrial relations portfolio because he has too much on his plate. In effect, he has admitted to his colleagues that he cannot handle his portfolio responsibilities. If we needed in this parliament any evidence at all of the minister's incapacity, the minister's inability, the minister's incompetence, we only have to look at the bill being debated in the parliament today.

PARA.TAB: This bill is a disgrace. Yet it is not the first disgrace brought into the parliament by the Minister for Industrial Relations. We all know about the Industrial Relations Act, which is now law. We all know how the Industrial Relations Act is condemning more and more Australians to the dole queue. We all know how this minister and this government have presided over record levels of unemployment. We all know that when the country is supposed to be moving out of recession we now have at least 800,000 people out of work and possibly up to 1,500,000 people unable to find sufficient work. This minister and this government have been a monumental disaster. Some families in Australia have had up to two and three generations of people who have not been able to get a job.

This government masquerades as the government of the underprivileged. This government is not the government of the underprivileged. This government is the government of the quick dollar. This is the government which in 11 years of office has presided over the gap between rich and poor in Australia growing to the widest gap existing in any OECD country.

This government will be defeated at the next election because the people of Australia are totally opposed to the way this government has operated, to the way it says one thing and does another, to the way it has proven that it is simply the spokesman of interest groups. Over the last 11 years, and more particularly since the Minister for Industrial Relations attained that position, this government has been the government of the unions by the unions for the unions.

This little piece of legislation is not being opposed by the opposition, but we take the view that it is too little too late. It will not achieve what it ought to achieve. We need to get rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal as soon as possible. The minister promised that it was going to go in April, but he has been opposed by unions. The minister has given in and has run up the white flag. The minister should be showing backbone. He should be getting in there and demanding that the Coal Industry Tribunal, which has been responsible for throwing lots of Australian mineworkers onto the job scrap heap, be totally scrapped. He should be concentrating on the social wreckage which is resulting from 11 years of Labor government and which sees one and half million Australians unable to find adequate work and at least 800,000 Australians out of work.

This government and this minister have failed the Australian people yet again. They have not told the truth. They have rolled over in favour of the union movement. What we need are some policies to get people into work. One policy that is very necessary is to get rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal, which has been responsible for so many bad decisions and so much mismanagement in the coal industry and so many ridiculous work practices which have cost jobs.

So the minister stands condemned for failing to carry out his promise to get rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal. The minister stands condemned for merely incorporating the Coal Industry Tribunal as part of the Industrial Relations Commission. Furthermore he stands condemned for insisting that the commission take into account and implement precedent decisions by the Coal Industry Tribunal which have been such a monumental disaster and which were the very reason that the minister in April this year said that the Coal Industry Tribunal had to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great delight that I rise to support my colleagues the member for Fisher (Mr Slipper) and the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles) in this important piece of legislation concerning the potential abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal. As the member for Fisher so rightly advocates, the Coal Industry Tribunal has been a very difficult and unhelpful industrial tribunal in the administration of the coal industry. This tribunal is the manifestation of the centralised industrial relations system that has been operating in Australia since 1908. As members on this side of the House have indicated time after time, the existence of the tribunal and now its incorporation into the Industrial Relations Commission are a matter of great concern to us, who have been advocating enterprise agreements and the flexibility that flows from such an industrial relations change.

PARA.TAB: In this situation it is clear that the coalminers have great and persuasive power over the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton). All the evidence we see before us in the parliament and the negotiations that have gone on indicate the power of Mr Maitland, the leader of the miners union, and the ability to overcome what was originally a sensible suggestion by the minister that the Coal Industry Tribunal should be abolished and that matters within the coal industry should move into the mainstream of industrial relations.

The coal industry, as both sides of the House know, is a very dangerous industry. Lives have been lost historically here in Australia and throughout the Western world as this difficult and arduous activity has taken place underground. The difficulties of gas, of hard manual activity and of ever present danger have encouraged a culture that in the long run has not always been helpful in the industrial relations sector. Let me place on record my understanding that this background has been the case on the waterfront, in the shearing industry and in other industries that I am familiar with. It has produced an attitude both by management and the work force that has not always been helpful in bringing about change.

I notice the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) was quite clear and up-front that he strongly supports the collective union approach, that the union movement should be able to put a point of view across all the mines in Queensland, New South Wales and the Hunter Valley area, which some members have been talking about in this parliament. Obviously, this collectivist view is very much against the philosophy of the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the honourable member for La Trobe and me. Our view is that we should be concentrating on a cooperative culture, in this case between the mineworkers and management in terms of safety, productivity and getting a better result.

The member for Gippsland (Mr McGauran) quite rightly pointed out in a well-researched speech that the closed shop arrangements working in the coal industry ensured that nobody outside the union membership, union families, would ever get a job in the coalmining towns. That really strikes at the level of opening up the industry to anyone else. Margaret Thatcher had a similar problem in the UK where the closed shop was predominant and only those people close to the mining industry could get a job. The member for Gippsland went on to talk about and incorporated in Hansard details of the very high level of strikes in the coalmining industry.

The honourable member for Bennelong, the shadow minister, drew the House's attention to the fact that the trade union was above the law, that union membership provided special privileges and again brought about the closed shop arrangement. Under this arrangement only those persons who have union membership could be considered under the Coal Industry Tribunal. We are suggesting and have seen in action similar situations at the Alcoa Point Henry aluminium plant. On previous occasions I have told members of this House about the wonderful activity that is going on in that plant. There are enterprise agreements between management and the work force. The work force is working in small groups and they enjoy their work. They have a very close eye on safety, productivity and profitability.

That is a far cry from the whole arrangement of this Coal Industry Tribunal where we have a fundamental tradition. We have management, the employees and this third party, which is interfering between those two groups. As anyone would know, it is really an industrial relations system out of Jurassic Park because we are moving on from that confrontation situation with the umpire in the middle. The Coal Industry Tribunal is a classic example of this. It goes back to the Chifley days—and I will mention that in a minute—when Ben Chifley was under considerable pressure, even as a Labor Prime Minister, to set up some mechanism. He adopted the usual Labor Party attitude that we must negotiate and we must put up what he saw as a fair and neutral umpire. We ended up with the Coal Industry Tribunal, which has survived so many years since its introduction.

This bill, as other members have said on this side, is a move to get the coal industry into the mainstream of industrial relations. However, its real effect is to guarantee the continuation of the tribunal as a subcommittee of the Industrial Relations Commission. From the original intention to get rid of it, we now see it as having some special privileges in the Industrial Relations Commission. In April the Minister for Industrial Relations promised to abolish the coal tribunal. That is what he suggested and that is what he put forward, and we agreed with that. Between then and now the minister has gradually backed down. He has moved away because of the pressure of the coalminers and their leader, Mr Maitland.

We now have a situation where the Coal Industry Tribunal effectively stays in position. It has got a new name, a new identity, a new facelift and a new wardrobe. Because it is now in the Industrial Relations Commission, it has got a certain amount of respectability. It becomes a specialist panel of the Industrial Relations Commission and the President of the Coal Industry Tribunal, Mr David Duncan, now becomes a presidential member of the IRC. Quite a remarkable turn of events! From a position of total abolition, it is now incorporated in the industrial relations club.

The other interesting thing is that the Industrial Relations Commission is to take into account past decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal. It has to `take into account'—let us just be clear about. Whilst the minister has made it clear that the Industrial Relations Commission is not bound by the past decisions, it is, however, to take them into account. It is my understanding that the minister made this very important change between the first reading of the bill and its current stage. Again, the miners union has been working on the minister to make sure that 40 years of tradition of industrial practice will now be incorporated and taken into account in the industrial relations tribunal. The minister should have got rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal. He has been unable to do this.

As I said before, the Coal Industry Tribunal came into existence in 1946, postwar Australia, when coal supply was very short and when keeping production going was the main concern of the government of the day. Industrial unrest was the norm for those who can remember. Even as a young Australian I can remember the concern that Australians had about the unrest in the coalfields and the current Labor government trying its best to maintain some semblance of normal arrangements between management and the coalminers.

The Coal Industry Tribunal had a highly adversarial nature. It was trying to stop some of the problems that employees and management got themselves into. The Chifley government, as we well recall, tried to avert strikes, lockouts and lost production. It was really set up in the first instance as a means of settling disputes between the two adversarial opponents—the workers and the employees. This third party again was drawn up to interfere, arbitrate and try to sort out the problems that quite correctly should have been sorted out between management and their employees at the coalface, so to speak. The Coal Industry Tribunal at that time was charged with the task of `facilitating increased production', whatever that might mean. We all know that it was really related to the industrial relations problem that emerged in these postwar years.

There was a perception that the Coal Industry Tribunal decisions had more to do with a quick return to work than assessing the various disputes on their merits in each case. There was considerable pressure on the national government to make sure that the miners went back to work to ensure the export of coal and the availability of coal for the power stations throughout Australia.

Even now the level of industrial disputation is very high in the coal industry. It accounts for less than one half of one per cent of the work force but 12 per cent of the time lost in strikes. That is quite a staggering statistic even in this modern age where a certain amount of sanity has come to the coal industry because of the pressures of overseas prices and some new arrangements in certain mines. There have been three national strikes in the last 14 months. It might even have something to do with the abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal.

I notice the member for Throsby is coming into the House. I am delighted to see that one member of the government is prepared at least to come into the chamber and defend his position. There is no other member of the government here to defend the abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal. The coal industry, as the member for Throsby would well know, is a very important export industry, exporting about $7 million a year, subject to international competition.

I noticed in some of the previous comments that the Coal Industry Tribunal has been trying to work on the way in which some of the coal prices have been set. The coal industry is subject to international competition in terms of quality, price and delivery and is not able to withstand the pressure from lack of delivery because of unwarranted strikes. There need to be working arrangements that are productive and competitive from a world perspective. Especially when power needs to be delivered at the domestic level, we need to set in place arrangements within the coal industry that ensure a whole new set of industrial relations attitudes.

It is worth noting that award rates are higher for coalminers than for miners and employees in other industries. For all the discussion about danger and productivity, we know that these rates are much higher than the rates paid to other workers. Over the last 10 years the wage premium in the coal industry has risen from 70 per cent of average weekly earnings to 85 per cent. Over the same period the proportion of those working underground has fallen from 70 per cent to around 40 per cent. As the member for Throsby would know, that fall in percentage reflects the movement of a number of personnel from arduous activity in dangerous underground areas to less dangerous and more mechanised activity which is employed in the open-cut method of mining.

Other differences really demonstrate these differentials between pay rates to workers in the coal industry and those of other workers around Australia. A fitter in the coal industry gets a base rate of $519 per week; a fitter elsewhere gets $425 per week. A clerk in the coal industry gets a base rate of pay of $505 per week; a clerk elsewhere gets $394 per week. Total earnings per week are also much higher in the coal industry: coalminers average $1,237 per week; other miners average $1,026 per week—and the rest of the economy averages $672 per week.

There are also generous sick leave, annual leave and long service leave entitlements that accrue to people working in the coal industry. This also means that there are rates of pay per hour that show even larger disparities. According to ACL, miners get $44 per effective hour. That is quite a staggering figure when you take into account all the coal industry overheads and add-ons. According to ACL, everyone else in Australia gets an average of $21 an hour. Of course, the important thing is flexibility of earnings. This is very limited because, as is being advocated by the member for Throsby, the mining unions want rates of pay to be the same across the board, even though some mines are more profitable and have different sets of conditions than others.

What we need in the culture of the coal industry is a shift away from the old style adversarial arrangements to a more cooperative bargaining system where management and employees can get together to solve some of the industry's problems. The total abolition of the Coal Industrial Tribunal would be a very symbolic step; it would show that the government's rhetoric was not only confined to the coal industry but also moving on to other industries.

Several enterprises feel frustration at the government's inactivity on labour market reform—it gives plenty of lip service to and rhetoric about how it has moved to enterprise bargaining. But, if you look at the details necessary for arrangements to be registered as an enterprise flexibility agreement—and that is a very interesting set of words, `enterprise flexibility agreement'—this is what you have to go through to get it in place. Parties must become respondents to the federal award. That is the first thing parties must do—so they are going back to the old industrial relations club. Secondly, they must notify the union associated with the award. So, even if the plant workers are not associated with the union, they have to let it know what is going on—and the union, of course, can become party to the deal. What does management around Australia do? It is not taking on enterprise flexibility agreements because of the ham-fisted and very bureaucratic arrangements it must now go through to adopt a policy which has been advocated by me and the member for La Trobe. Finally, of course, the parties must satisfy themselves in these enterprise flexibility agreements, through specific tests, that there is no disadvantage, no discrimination and that they are in the public interest. How can anyone, who wants to make any progress in the whole arena of industrial relations, who finds there is a genuine arrangement between the employees and the employer to get a better set of working conditions, put up with all of that?

I will spend a couple of moments considering the Woodside offshore petroleum operation in the North West Shelf. I have been there with you, Mr Deputy Speaker, and others, and have talked to management about its enterprise agreements and the way in which it has been able to change the culture of its particular operation. Woodside is a very big project. Some $12 billion has been injected into exporting LNG to Japan and supplying natural gas to the Western Australian market. It is obviously under considerable pressure in terms of supplying the gas on time to its export market and in making sure that the quality and time constraints accord with its contracts over five to 10 years.

However, over the last couple of years the company has been seeking to improve its productivity and quality control and has sought to come to some arrangement with its 300 to 400 workers at Karratha. It sought an enterprise agreement, which was worth an extra 10 to 15 per cent to the employees, to bring about a reform of work practices and produce more flexible arrangements within the plant and on the offshore platforms so that the whole operation would work more efficiently and effectively.

The ACTU, the AWU and the firemen and electrical trades unions opposed this deal; they were dead against it; they did not want to have anyone coming to an arrangement between the workers and management. However, in the end, the unions backed down because, by secret ballot—and I draw this to the attention of the member for Throsby—the workers indicated that a margin of 75 per cent of them preferred to be on staff. That group wanted to join staff because they found they could get work which was more satisfactory. They found there were more flexible arrangements to suit families and the way they worked in these very hot conditions and that they could help the company's profitability and thereby keep their jobs. If they retained the old arrangements under strict awards with union interference, a number of them were going to lose their jobs. So that was a situation where a well-known, very responsible company had brought about enterprise agreements, even in the face of considerable pressure not to do so by the trade union movement. The Coal Industrial Tribunal is an example of what should not be done in Australia. In the long term, it will meet its demise in the Industrial Relations Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cobb Mr M.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is primarily about getting rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal by absorbing it into the mainstream industrial relations system with the eventual aim of abolishing it altogether. Initially, this was to be done in two stages. But I now see that the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Brereton) has taken up the coalition's suggestions and is apparently going to do it in one stage—and, to that extent, we would welcome it. It has been a long and tortuous process getting to the present position. We have had three legislative positions put to us over a period of time.
—He's flexible.

—He is flexible in that and other areas—he is the minister for backflips. Unlike all other workers in this country employed under federal awards, workers in the coal industry have enjoyed their own industrial relations arrangements through the 1946 coal industry legislation. If you are a unionist or employer in the coal industry, you have had to work within the specialist area of the Coal Industry Tribunal which has had jurisdiction over industrial disputes in this country. I notice the administration costs in New South Wales alone amount to $1.2 million a year. Though the mechanisms vary from state to state according to whether you have an intrastate or interstate dispute, this position has applied for some period of time, whereas the rest of Australia has had to use the Industrial Relations Commission or, as it is now called, the Industrial Relations Court.

PARA.TAB: The coal industry has traditionally been a fairly militant industry, often presided over by fairly dictatorial and belligerent union leaders. Because it is a very high capital cost area, the coal unions have had enormous leverage or muscle which they have used from time to time—I think often to the detriment of the interests of the country and of the coal industry itself. I do not deny for a moment that workers in the coal industry should be very well rewarded. Indeed, members of my own family and relatives have had a long history of working in the coal industry on the surface and underground and, in particular, in the area of industry safety. The coal industry, I stress, is a very important industry to Australia. It is the biggest export earner we have in this country now by a long margin.

I believe the workers in the coal industry and the coal industry as a whole could have done much better without some of the lurks and rorts that have been put in place due, in large part, to the Coal Industry Tribunal. In one of the coalmines, three pit ponies were still being used in the 1980s. It took many years to get rid of them—a crazy situation. How could something like that exist in a modern era?

From last year to the end of June this year, 171,000 working days were lost in the coal industry. One-half of a per cent of the work force accounted for about 12 per cent of the working days lost in this country, a ratio of 24 to one. It is true that in past years the coal industry has been relatively profitable, and the unions have exploited this point mercilessly. But recently, with a world recession and with a plunge in commodity prices, the chickens have come home to roost in this industry. Energy costs for commodities have fallen in the oil industry, the gas industry and the uranium industry perhaps more so than in the coal industry. Members of the coal industry unions have been running around trying to put the screws on the Japanese for some reason, saying that they have been screwing coal prices in Australia more so than in any other industry. I invite them to look at the fall of energy prices in all those industries. The coal industry has been far from the leader in that area.

Australia has led the world in mining industry technology and inventions over the years. We have led the world in flotation, cabling, drilling and exploration techniques, which has led to efficiencies which have been largely passed on to those industries. In some areas the coal industry has dragged its feet because of the intransigence of the unions.

The Coal Industry Tribunal, in some of its judgments, has been slow to implement the benefits of these discoveries to the detriment of all. In 1985 the Hancock report virtually recommended the abolition of the Coal Industry Tribunal. Now, in 1994, almost a decade later, we have legislation before the parliament to do that. It seems that Minister Brereton, the present minister, has been a disaster in whatever he has touched. We have seen examples of that with ANL, the Civil Aviation Authority, industrial relations, particularly with his unfair dismissals legislation, and now with the shifts in ground in relation to the Coal Industry Tribunal.
I was interested to see a letter on my desk signed by Peter Barrack, the Secretary of the Newcastle Trades Hall Council, addressed to his ALP colleagues. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Colleague,

We must again, in the strongest terms and out of due concern for the credibility of the Labor Government, protest against the retention of Laurie Brereton as Minister for Industrial Relations and Transport.
To mention the Minister's name in any forum of working people and Labour supporters is to bring howls of derision, anger and outbursts of obscenities against him.

Have members of the Government forgotten that because of Minister Brereton's widespread unpopularity, even Barrie Unsworth had to remove him from positions of prominence as he was considered an electoral liability?
In the Hunter region it is argued forcibly that Laurie was indirectly responsible for the loss of the two safest seats in NSW ie. Swansea and Newcastle in the 1987 NSW elections.

The Government should be warned that while Laurie Brereton remains Minister for Industrial Relations it will not be possible to mobilise the level of rank and file involvement in the electoral process that was achieved in 1993. There will be passive non participation.

He ends the letter with, `Fraternal Greetings, Peter Barrack, Secretary.' That is what his own supposed supporters think of him. He has been called the minister for disasters, the minister for chaos and the minister for backflips. I have read of numerous reports in papers where the Prime Minister has labelled him as `Danger Man', which I think is fairly appropriate under the circumstances considering the trouble that he has been in in this House alone over the last couple of months.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the amendment moved to this bill by the shadow minister for industrial relations, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), the government never ceases to amaze me with the selective manner in which it signs international treaties relating to industrial relations and other matters and then, upon doing so, insists on implementing in a very selective manner only those things in the treaties which suit it. A classic example is the enforcement of compulsory unionism. A clear denial of a basic human right exists within this country today, namely, the right to join a trade union. Opinion polls have predicted that at least 75 to 80 per cent of the population have consistently said that people should have the right if they wish not to join a trade union. But I do not see the government rushing forward with any legislation to implement this.

There has been no suggestion of freedom in the coal industry, where compulsory unionism is the norm. If you are not a member of the trade union, quite frankly you do not get a start. It is as simple as that. At the moment the coal industry is presided over by the United Mineworkers Federation, which has as its umbrella the CFMEU. The United Mineworkers Federation has about 21,000 miners. As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), has said, the average wage is about $1,200 per week. I do not deny them that for a moment, but I would like to see some of the work practices in that area improved. The president of that union is John Maitland, known colloquially as Mario. It is interesting to read some of the things that have been said about this fellow, a colourful character if ever there were one. An article in the Age recently said that he was leading a strike in Collinsville, a coalmining town in Queensland which had brought down some security checks on the workers to stop pilfering. Mr Maitland said:

SPEECH.PARA: When I lived here, they could have got any one of us!

Others spoke of pilfering as `traditional and part of the company's contribution to the town' when denouncing the recent security clampdown. Apparently, the company was trying to bring in what normal Australians would have thought were proper work practices—namely, the elimination of pilfering—and had to back down. Such is the culture of the coal unions in this country.

PARA.TAB: One of the union officials, a fellow called `Moscow' Brunker, said that the company brought in a new human resources manager, a woman, who apparently proposed that it would be a civilised thing for the two of them to sit down and have a drink together at the workers club to see what they could work out. What did the union official think of that? The article in the Age states:
Moscow laughs and laughs at the idea.
"I told her she could drink there, but not with me!
"The boys'd think I was a traitor—they hired a woman to disarm us; she thought she was gunna make us respectable. That's why, at our first meeting with her, we decided to go in hard.
"Honestly," he hoots, "I've never `f . . . d' and `c . . . d' so much in my life!"

Later, responding to one of Moscow's elaborated toasts, Maitland says: "Everything I've achieved I owe to Collinsville. This is where I had my opportunity to be nurtured, and to allow my political ambitions and attitudes to mature."

SPEECH.PARA: As soon as we can get rid of the Coal Industry Tribunal and bring this union into the mainstream the better. The united mineworkers union will have to be dragged into the 1994 ethos that is now starting to exist in this country, even with all its faults.

PARA.TAB: I urge the members of this House to condemn the way in which the minister has handled the portfolio, whether from the position of unfair dismissals, the abolition of sections 45D and E of the Trade Practices Act or the numerous changes and backflips that he has made in this portfolio. I point out the deficiencies that exist in this bill, and I urge everyone here to support the coalition's amendment.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRERETON

TALK.START.PARA: —I make the following points in respect of the contributions of the opposition in this second reading debate on the Industrial Relations Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). Once again, we have seen this very important industrial relations reform, but we have seen the response of the opposition—one characterised by total irrelevance to the issues under consideration. We have had a preview of a totally irrelevant second reading amendment. If ever I have seen a case of tired old contributions with the same thing being parroted speaker after speaker, this was certainly it.

PARA.TAB: The most I think anyone can say about this debate is that the opposition either does not understand the government's proposal—that is the most charitable interpretation one can put on it—or is wilfully misrepresenting it. I am sure that, as far as the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) is concerned, he is flat out down that second path.

The bill, as it will be amended and passed by this House, will do precisely what the government set out to do—that is, bring industrial relations regulation in the coalmining industry into the mainstream of Australian industrial relations. The opposition in the course of this debate has questioned the creation of a coalmining panel within the structure of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. This is exactly the legal requirement that applies to every industry. It does not matter what industry it is, there is a panel charged with the responsibility of looking after that industry area under the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. It is not a requirement that people will find in this bill because it is already contained, fully outlined, in section 37 of the Industrial Relations Act 1988.

In addition, in the course of this debate, the opposition has suggested that our proposed amendments will result in the commission being bound by previous decisions of the Coal Industry Tribunal. Let me say for the 99th time—and let those opposite get it into their heads—that this is simply untrue. I made this abundantly clear in the second reading speech. If the opposition wants any further enlightenment I am more than happy to provide it during the consideration of the government's amendments.

All I can suggest to those opposite is that they give some further consideration to the role of the opposition, because it has not been fulfilled in the course of this debate. It is not a question of coming into the chamber and engaging in time wasting point scoring, nor is it a hopeless search for some non-existent faults in a reform which has tripartite support. No amount of beating around the bush, no amount of obfuscation, no amount of misrepresentation by the opposition can alter the fact that this reform is endorsed by the government, the industry, the employers and the union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what galling them.

—It is the fact that the united mineworkers have endorsed this reform that really sticks in their craw. That is the one thing they cannot stand. The Labor Party, once again, without any time lost in the industry, has been able to achieve fundamental reform through the mechanisms of the accord and has been able to achieve what you in all your years could never do and what Ian Macphee said to me he tried to do in implementing Liberal Party policy though he was blocked in the cabinet of the day by none other than Doug Anthony.
—Doug was right.

—Say all you like. The fact is you could never get your act together and achieve such a reform. If anything, in the course of this debate, we have seen illustrated the total intellectual bankruptcy of those sitting opposite and the policies that they pursue. I commend the legislation to the House.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1994Cognate bills:INCOME TAX (FORMER COMPLYING SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1994INCOME TAX (FORMER NON-RESIDENT SUPERANNUATION FUNDS) BILL 1994INCOME TAX RATES AMENDMENT BILL 1994INCOME TAX (DEFICIT DEFERRAL) BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed from 13 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elliott Mr R.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1994 will amend the taxation laws in a number of respects. It includes measures which give effect to certain announcements in the 1994-95 budget and the Working Nation white paper of 4 May 1994.

PARA.TAB: The bill will give effect to the 1994-95 budget announcement by the Treasurer (Mr Willis) on 10 May 1994 that employee share benefits provided by an employer to an employee in respect of employment will be subject to fringe benefits tax, FBT. Transitional arrangements will apply so that in certain circumstances the existing provisions of the income tax law will continue to apply to shares, or rights to shares, acquired after 10 May 1994.

The government is making these changes to reduce the exploitation of the existing legislation and to ensure that the tax concessions that are available under the new arrangements are directed at share schemes which encourage employees to own shares in the company by which they are employed or in a holding company of their employer. The measures will significantly increase the taxation benefits available under schemes which encourage investment by employees in their employer company and which are available to all permanent employees on a fair and equitable basis.

The bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986, FBTAA, so that FBT will be imposed on employee share fringe benefits which arise when an employee, or associate, acquires shares, or rights to shares, for an amount less than the market value. The amount subject to FBT will be reduced by any amount paid by the employee or associate.

Two concessions are available which can further reduce the taxable value of the benefit where certain criteria are satisfied. These concessions are referred to as the `exemption concession' and the `deferral concession'. The `exemption concession' is available where there are restrictions on the sale or disposal of the shares or rights and where the restrictions exceed a five-year holding period. Where this concession is used, the taxable value of the benefit can be reduced by up to $500.

The `deferral concession' is available where there are restrictions on the sale or disposal of the shares or rights and where the restrictions exceed a five-year holding period but do not extend beyond 10 years. Where this concession is used, the taxable value of the benefit can be reduced by up to $1,500. An amount will be included in the employee's assessable income in the year in which the restrictions on the shares or rights cease.

The proposed amendments will allow an employer to claim an income tax deduction for the amount of the exemption or deferral concession. The bill will also amend the capital gains provisions to ensure that the advantage gained by the concessions will not be `clawed back' through those provisions. The nature of these measures is such that a reliable estimate of the revenue impact cannot be provided. The government will be moving some clarifying amendments to the employee share acquisition scheme provisions of the bill during the consideration in detail stage.

The bill will amend the research and development tax concessions to give effect to the changes announced in the Working Nation white paper. The first change is that the shading-in rules, which currently apply where a company's research and development expenditure is between $20,000 and $50,000, will be eliminated. The full 150 per cent deduction will be allowable for the 1994-95 and later years of income where the total research and development expenditure is more than $20,000.

The second change will extend the concession to expenditure incurred on certain research and development activities undertaken outside Australia. Expenditure incurred on research and development activities conducted outside Australia must be given prior approval by the Industry Research and Development Board. The Industry Research and Development Act 1986 will be amended to give the board power to develop public guidelines specifying the criteria that companies must satisfy for their activities to be approved by the board. Some of those criteria are to be set by these amendments.

The third change will amend the Industry Research and Development Act to reduce the expenditure threshold from $1 million to $500,000 for companies registering jointly on or after 1 July 1994 in respect of a proposed research and development project starting on or after that date. This change will facilitate the use of syndicate structures for smaller research and development projects, which is expected to benefit small to medium sized companies.

The reduced expenditure threshold is estimated to cost the revenue $2 million per annum from 1995-96. The tax deductibility of expenditure on overseas R&D activities cannot be quantified, but it is expected to have some cost to revenue. The reduced expenditure threshold for syndicates is estimated to cost the revenue $4 million per annum from 1995-96.

In the Working Nation white paper, the government announced that the rate of tax on income derived by a pooled development fund, PDF, from its investments in small and medium sized enterprises, SMEs, would be reduced from 25 per cent to 15 per cent. This change, which is designed to increase the attractiveness of the PDF program to investors, will apply to the assessments of PDFs for the 1994-95 and later years of income.

The bill will divide the taxable income of a PDF into two components: income from investing in small and medium enterprises will be taxed at 15 per cent and income from other sources will be taxed at 25 per cent. Simple rules will allocate the allowable deductions, capital gains and capital losses of a PDF between the two components of taxable income. The measure is estimated to cost the revenue nil in 1994-95, $3 million in 1995-96, $4 million in 1996-97 and $4 million in 1997-98.

The bill contains amendments to give effect to some changes relating to superannuation. These changes include clarifying the existing treatment of overseas superannuation funds and payments related to them. They will also ensure that tax concessions for superannuation contributions and benefits are limited to retirement benefits which accumulate in superannuation funds that comply with Australian regulations and that Australian tax concessions are not diverted to non-residents.

The amendments will recoup tax concessions given to superannuation funds that change their status from complying to non-complying and impose tax on funds which change their status from non-resident to resident. The Income Tax (Former Complying Superannuation Funds) Bill 1994 and the Income Tax (Former Non-Resident Superannuation Funds) Bill 1994 impose these taxes.

The bill will also subject to fringe benefits tax employer contributions paid to a non-complying superannuation fund in certain circumstances. In addition, the bill contains amendments to the Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 to restrict complying status to resident superannuation funds and resident approved deposit funds and to specify the circumstances in which a superannuation fund could lose its complying status. The bill also makes minor consequential amendments to the Income Tax Act 1986 and the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Act 1992.

As part of the consultative process, the Treasurer released draft provisions for the measures contained in the bill on 30 June 1994. Several changes have been made to the draft provisions to reflect comments received. In particular, the bill contains measures to specify the exceptional circumstances in which a superannuation fund will become a non-complying fund. The proposal to tax superannuation funds that change their status from complying to non-complying or from non-resident to resident has been delayed until the 1995-96 income year.

In addition, the bill excludes from fringe benefits tax employer contributions paid to a non-resident superannuation fund for the benefit of expatriate employees who are in Australia temporarily for a period of up to four years. The measures are expected to have a minimal effect on the revenue.

On 9 September 1994, the Treasurer announced retrospective amendments to the income tax law relating to the tax treatment of surpluses repatriated to an employer from a superannuation fund. The amendments ensure that any payment or benefit from a superannuation fund, other than a payment or benefit to a member, is included in the assessable income of the recipient. The purpose of the amendments is to overcome arrangements entered into by taxpayers whereby the surplus from an employer sponsored superannuation fund is repatriated to the sponsoring employer, or an associate of the sponsoring employer, in a way which avoids the payment of tax on receipt of the surplus. Those arrangements are in breach of the clear thrust of the existing law and represent a serious threat to the revenue.

To allow surpluses to be repatriated tax free would also give an undeserved benefit to employers at the expense of the taxpayer community in general. Therefore, the proposed amendments apply from 1 July 1988. The financial impact of the proposed amendments is difficult to quantify. However, the measure will remove scope for substantial revenue leakage.

The income tax law generally taxes certain income of minors at a higher rate to prevent taxpayers diverting their income to children for the purposes of avoiding their proper tax responsibilities. In recognition that not all unearned income of minors should be taxed at a higher rate, the law was intended to relieve from taxation at the higher rate income derived by a minor from the investment of property transferred to the minor as part of a legal settlement in connection with a family breakdown. However, the law did not achieve this because the words used in the relevant relief provisions are inconsistent with the Family Law Act 1975. Amendments in the bill will ensure that the parliament's original intention to provide relief is fulfilled.

Other amendments will clarify the anti-avoidance provisions relating to a minor's unearned income. Specifically, the amendments will continue to limit the relief from the higher tax rate to ensure that the amount qualifying for relief is no more than an arm's length rate of return on the property transferred. The amendment of the anti-avoidance provisions will prevent a potential loss to the revenue of around $6 million per year.

Under the existing income tax law, successful cash bids for the granting of offshore petroleum titles are deductible over 10 years or the life of the petroleum field, whichever is the lesser. The bill proposes to extend this deduction to successful cash bids for onshore and overseas petroleum titles and to onshore, offshore and overseas mineral titles.

The measures are consistent with the government's general approach to taxation policy, which is to enhance equity between taxpayers and remove obstacles to worthwhile investment. The bill will ensure that Australian explorers and miners operating overseas are not disadvantaged, whether they operate onshore, offshore or overseas in making cash bids; all successful bids will have the same Australian tax treatment, and so no area of bidding will be comparatively advantaged or disadvantaged.The cost of the amendments to the revenue will be less than $1 million per annum.
The bill will modify the company tax imputation system in two respects.

First, it will introduce new provisions to bring the imputation system into line with the new company tax instalment arrangements. Under these arrangements, companies other than those with small tax liabilities will pay their income tax by quarterly instalment. The amendments will permit companies to pass on to their shareholders the imputation benefits that flow from the earlier payment of company tax instalments. The bill also contains provisions to ensure that companies cannot pass imputation benefits on to shareholders without paying the tax that the imputation credits represent.

The Income Tax (Deficit Deferral) Bill 1994 will impose deficit deferral on companies in certain circumstances to ensure that the tax is paid. The new provisions will apply to payments and refunds of company tax relating to the 1994-95 and later years of income for small and medium sized instalment taxpayers, and the 1995-96 and later years of income for large instalment taxpayers. The new provisions are not expected to have a significant revenue impact.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Early Payments of Company Tax for 1993-94

PARA.TAB: The bill will also modify the operation of the imputation provisions to deal with the early payment of company tax for the 1993-

SPEECH.PARA: 94 income year. The government last year reduced the general company tax rate from 39 per cent to 33 per cent with effect from the 1993-94 income year. The amendment in this bill is a transitional measure which will ensure that total imputation credits attached to dividends cannot exceed the company tax paid out. The amendment will prevent a potential loss to revenue of around $1 million.
Payment of Interest on Overpayments and Early Payments

PARA.TAB: The bill introduces further changes to improve the self-assessment system of taxation by making the interest regime more fair and equitable. It will complement the interest provisions for late and underpayments of income tax by expanding the scope for interest to be paid on overpayments of income tax and providing for interest to be paid on early payments of income tax.

The current law only allows for payment of interest on overpayments of income tax in limited circumstances. The proposed changes will widen the circumstances in which taxpayers will be entitled to receive interest on overpayments. Interest under the new overpayment arrangements will be payable in respect of the overpayments that relate to 1993-94 and later years.

The bill will provide for interest to be paid to a taxpayer when income tax is paid more than 14 days before the date the amount is due and payable. This will apply to early payments of income tax, provisional tax and instalments of tax.Interest on early payments will apply to payments made in respect of liabilities for 1993-94 and later years. The financial impact of the interest on overpayments changes is estimated to be $1.7 million in 1994-95 and $1 million in subsequent years. Interest on early payments is estimated to cost $200,000 in 1995-96 and $130,000 in later years.

The bill contains amendments to ensure that the rate of interest used in calculating the superannuation guarantee charge is preserved at 10 per cent after 30 June 1994. The amendments will prevent a loss to employees of around $80,000 in superannuation guarantee charges distributed for their benefit.

The bill proposes to make a technical amendment to clarify the meaning of a term used to determine how much tax is paid by a credit union. The term was introduced as a result of amendments made in the budget last year. The Income Tax Rates Amendment Bill 1994 proposes a technical amendment to the Income Tax Rates Act 1986 to make a small change to reduce by $1 the tax threshold for medium credit unions. This amendment corrects the threshold so that it applies as originally intended and is consistent with the related provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. There is no cost to the revenue from the proposed changes because they ensure that the law applies as originally intended.

The bill also makes a minor amendment to the Development Allowance Authority Act 1992. Full details of the bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum circulated to honourable members. I am very pleased to commend Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 4) to the House.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Vietnam Veterans: Exposure to Toxic Chemicals

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles Mr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I will bring to the parliament and the nation a letter I have received from Mr Alan Ashmore of 2 Karen Street, Selby. He begins:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Mr Charles,

PARA.EMPHASIS: RE: VIETNAM VETERANS EXPOSURE TO TOXIC CHEMICALS:

SPEECH.PARA: I would be pleased if you will table the following letter in Parliament.
I intend to read Mr Ashmore's letter into Hansard. It states:

The recent revelations by Professors MacLennan and Smith, and acceptance by the Australian Government, of a clear link between a range of cancers and exposure to herbicides whilst on service in Vietnam, is welcomed. These latest findings are what Veterans have always suspected and this belated confirmation will be helpful to them and their families.

It has taken fifteen years for Vietnam Veterans to have their strong suspicions of the increased incidence of cancers confirmed. They have been equally concerned and vocal over the same period about the high incidence of birth defects amongst their children.
It is also suspected amongst the same veterans that exposure to herbicides whilst on active service may be responsible for cancers in their children.

My now 12 year old Son was diagnosed with Leukaemia almost ten years ago. He suffered two relapses but was fortunate his young sister had compatible bone marrow. A transplant took place in 1989. My Son is now cured of his cancer but now has a chemotherapy induced heart condition.

After the admission last month, which clearly showed that a Senate Committee and the Evatt Royal Commission were in error to proclaim Agent Orange not guilty, my Son is asking questions like, "Did this cause my leukaemia?". I am sure that disabled children of Vietnam Veterans are echoing the same type of question. It's a question their parents are unable to answer with authority.

Fifteen years ago Veterans observed a high suicide rate in fellow Veterans and high rates of cancer and birth defects in their children. It has taken fifteen years to have been proved correct. How much longer is it going to take before our children, whether they have birth defects or cancer, are told the truth?
As successive Governments have had fifteen years to investigate claims of birth defects and increased incidence of cancer in veterans children, I ask the government:

In light of the overturning of the findings of a Senate Committee and a Royal Commission will the government now commission rigorous independent investigations to determine if Veterans strong suspicions in these areas will again be confirmed?
I believe the least the government can do is to provide our children with concrete answers.
Yours faithfully,
Alan Ashmore.

Alan Ashmore is a thoughtful man. He is a man of the highest integrity who deserves to have his question answered. I know Alan well, as he is the driving force behind an organisation dedicated to serve young people in my electorate. This organisation is known as ECHO, the Emerald Club for Hope and Outreach. Every week hundreds of young people come together to learn how to be leaders in the community and how to respect Christian moral values. They are given activities which help them to interact with each other, to not get into trouble, to not resort to graffiti, to not go out on the streets and to not resort to drugs and alcohol. This youth group has been one of the most effective that I have seen anywhere in the world. Alan Ashmore is the man who created it. He is indeed a well-respected member of the community.

PARA.TAB: The importance of Alan's letter is that I am certain it was sent in all sincerity. He asks us in this place who represent him, the people of my electorate of La Trobe and indeed the people throughout the nation to consider most carefully this most important question of birth defects and cancer in the children of Vietnam veterans. I do not know the right or the wrong of the issue, but I do believe that veterans and their wives and offspring deserve honest and careful evaluation of their suspicions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I wish to draw attention to an important banking and finance issue in my state of Western Australia. I do so in my capacity as a Western Australian; as the federal member for Perth, in which most of the administrative headquarters of Western Australian financial institutions are based; and also as an interested member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Banking, Finance and Public Administration, which Mr Speaker has chaired well in the past.

PARA.TAB: This issue has been the subject of public comment in recent days in Western Australia. It requires careful consideration and serious analysis. I refer to the proposed privatisation of Bankwest, which is the state owned Rural and Industries Bank which has recently been renamed, and the possible merger with Challenge Bank, which is a private bank not in public ownership.

Subject to a couple of points in respect of ensuring the headquarters remain in Western Australia and attention to involuntary staff reductions, I think the privatisation of Bankwest is a good thing and good policy. I also think that the merger with Challenge is a good thing and good policy. I hope the Western Australian state government agrees to it. Why I think that merger is a good thing is summarised in one essential point: it would leave Western Australia with one strong regional bank, which would be good for the state and good for the inhabitants of Western Australia. Some members might be aware, particularly those from Western Australia, that in recent days Challenge Bank has announced what I describe as its $100 million-plus offer by way of merger; that is, whatever is proposed to be raised by the privatisation of Bankwest, Challenge argues that with a merger it can raise finance by $100 million more.

I was pleased to hear the Premier of Western Australia saying that he would not be rushed or bulldozed into a decision on this matter. I think that is right. This is a serious policy issue for the state which requires serious consideration and which needs to be looked at carefully. While on the surface the Challenge offer or proposal seems to be an attractive option, there may well be other issues which go to the benefit of the state, which have not yet been the subject of public comment and which the government of Western Australia is currently considering. The argument that the Challenge offer is worthy of consideration is best summarised in a couple of articles in newspapers of Friday, 11 November. In the Age, under the heading `Challenge's BankWest offer hard to reject', Stephen Bartholomeusz says:
The Challenge proposal ought, however, to be irresistable because it . . . would produce a substantially higher return to the Government than any other option.

SPEECH.PARA: Towards the end of the article, he says:
The only concerns for state government vendors ought to be price and residual risk. On both counts . . . a merger looks better than a simple float.
In the Australian Financial Review of the same date, Ivor Ries says:

PARA.TAB: The case for merging Challenge Bank and BankWest is compelling. It has been estimated that the merger would boost the profits attributable to the organisation by around $40 million.

SPEECH.PARA: That explains the nature of the offer and why this issue is obviously deserving of serious consideration. It would be good policy and good for Western Australia for the merger to proceed because, as I have said, it would leave Western Australia with a strong regional bank. It is acknowledged on all sides that there are, as described in the trade, substantial synergies between the two banks; that is, they would be a good fit and a good mix. It would minimise the risk of losses in any market share that might occur from the privatisation. Western Australia would have one regional bank, rather than two competing out of a limited pool. It would be more secure from possible takeover threat from the eastern states. But the key compelling point is that it would provide Western Australia with a strong regional bank with better international access.

PARA.TAB: I refer again to the article by Stephen Bartholomeusz in the Age. He says:

The merger of two WA banks would produce substantial synergies but would minimise the risk of market share losses that normally occur in bank mergers . . . It would create a $12 billion bank—about three times the size of Challenge—and would ensure that there weren't two WA institutions of modest size competing for the limited pool of funding and assets available.
It would have about one-third of the WA market . . . would probably be more secure from takeover than either of the individual banks, given the presence of the other.

SPEECH.PARA: He goes on to say:

PARA.TAB: Both banks are supported by the capital markets and a larger, more efficient and more profitable bank could only expect to gain better support and better access to international markets.
