SPEECH.SPEAKER: Atkinson Mr R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 November the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) announced a $183 million package aimed at reducing the impact of aircraft noise on residents living around Sydney airport. The package was largely based on the July 1994 draft noise management plan by consultants Mitchell McCotter. However, at the last moment the government extended its offer of insulation to public buildings, such as schools and hospitals, in inner Sydney that the consultants did not originally consider were in a noisy enough area to warrant expenditure on soundproofing. This added a further $8.4 million to the original $175 million cost. On 1 November the minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: The implications of this decision for other similarly affected airports are being examined.

Yet the Public Affairs Director of the Federal Airports Corporation, Mr Peter Arnold, was quoted in the Herald-Sun of 11 November, after I raised the matter of equal treatment for Moorabbin airport area public buildings, as saying:
There were no plans to extend the federal government's noise compensation. If that were to happen, other airports would be higher up the list than Moorabbin.

Why the apparent contradiction between the minister's statement and that of a key government authority? My office has had many complaints about aircraft noise in and around the Moorabbin airport area over the past few years. The Federal Airports Corporation admits that the number of complaints it has received so far this year is slightly up compared with 1993.

PARA.TAB: The Sydney consultants say that, at forecast noise levels of 25 to 30 on the scale used, between 20 and 30 per cent of people will be seriously affected by noise and another 40 per cent moderately affected. Yet this government—and I stress that this is not the fault of the FAC—now refuses to give similar offers of insulation to public buildings such as Parkdale Secondary College in Isaacs, whose 700-strong community is subjected daily to between 25 and 30 Australian noise exposure index contours.

The Mitchell McCotter report made it clear that an actual reading of 25 to 30 for a school was unacceptable. The table drawn up by the consultants referred to Australian noise exposure forecasts rather than actual readings. So in inner Sydney, a number of schools will be insulated, when the amount of noise they are assessed as suffering is only a forecast based on projections to the year 2010—16 years away—when Sydney airport may be at full capacity.

Pandering to Sydneysiders while ignoring the same difficulties faced by residents around Moorabbin, Adelaide and other airports is most unfair. Surely, if you are a student at Parkdale and you take almost a year to get accustomed to the noise of aircraft movements, you should have the same expectations as a Sydney school student that your school will have the same acoustic treatment.

My constituents have other reasons to be unhappy with the government. The new 650 stall market at Moorabbin airport was opened recently without a planning permit. My constituents are also being denied the opportunity for lower domestic air fares that the entry of Air New Zealand might bring. But, most of all, residents near Moorabbin airport want a fair go and insulation for one of the worst affected public buildings—Parkdale Secondary College. That would be most welcome.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I made my maiden speech in this House 20 months ago, I mentioned that child care in parliament was a very important issue. I am happy to say that there has been some progress on this matter. I think the House would benefit from knowing what steps have been taken, Mr Speaker, especially in regard to your role and that of the Joint House Department.

PARA.TAB: Many members of parliament have young children, and when they come to Canberra to visit it is essential that they have somewhere where they can spend their time without disrupting the member's office. My good friend and colleague the member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) has a daughter who has just turned one and a son who has turned three, and he tells me that he is very pleased that we have now made some progress in this field.

There are usually only one or two weeks of the year when school aged children such as my own are able to join us here during the school holidays. Perhaps for those in the Senate, there would be even more of these dates.

Although there is a need for child-care facilities for staff and departmental members, due to parliamentary sitting patterns such facilities are probably not exactly what we require as members of parliament. So it was necessary to take a two-pronged approach. Arising out of discussions with your good self, Mr Speaker, there was the idea that in the International Year of the Family it would be appropriate to rename the Spouses Lounge the Family Lounge and make this a family friendly parliament. I am pleased to say that this idea has been taken up. Also, I think we should thank the Parliamentary Partners who, when they were approached on this suggestion, agreed to it and have been very cooperative.

On 21 November work will commence in-house to make some adjustments to the room which was previously the Spouses Lounge—and which now, I am pleased to say, has the name `Family Lounge' on it—to make it child safe. This will require some small changes, such as removing part of the carpeted area, taking out the hot water system, relocating a nappy disposal unit and also supplying a nappy changing table for babies, and putting in some low tables for children to play on. Also, parliamentarians will be able to donate suitable videos, games, books and other activities material for their children to use in this room.

I commend the Joint House Department for a very sensible initiative in relocating existing resources that everyone may benefit from, especially as members are required to visit their children but still be in four-minute call of the chamber when they are needed for their work. Either the member's spouse or his or her nominee can supervise the children in the Family Lounge. Of course, older children will not require supervision.

As to the other issue, which is that of child care for staff, members should be aware that a child-care centre is located in the new Foreign Affairs and Trade building which will be open in 1996. Some places have been earmarked for people working in the parliament to have access to that centre.

A lot of work has been done by the Joint House Department in liaising with private child-care facilities to provide a child-care facility within the Parliamentary Triangle. To this effect, in February a survey will be conducted of all employees in the parliament asking them for details. We must remember that there are five departments at work in Parliament House, as well as journalists and the staff of members. Of course, during sitting times the number of people working in the parliament can swell up to 4,000.

This survey has been particularly adapted for those people who require child-care facilities. It is not a classic case of asking, `Do you require child-care, and if so what?' It is going to be looking at the special needs of the parliament—the hours required, broken placements, occasional care, holiday activities, et cetera. This survey has been devised in conjunction with work and child-care services, so it will, hopefully, be able to answer a number of the requirements that staff members have. It is hoped that a private child-care centre will be built within the Parliamentary Triangle that will meet the specific needs that come out of this survey.

In conclusion, I make the comment that Jill Baker from the Joint House Department, who has overseen a lot of the detail of this project, has demonstrated a mother's touch that has been evident in a lot of the things that have been brought in. There are some splendid ideas which do not involve any cost in terms of taxpayers' money, just some good commonsense which I am sure all members will benefit from. Hopefully, the staff will be able to have their needs met as well. The entire department needs to be thanked. We must also resolve that this is not just a women's issue; it is a people's issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to talk about one of the most exciting inventions this country has ever seen and to tell how the present government has bungled the assistance that was due to helping this discovery come to commercial fruition. I refer to a small company based in Sydney, Intec Copper Pty Ltd, which has continued the great Australian tradition of pioneering mining inventions by discovering a chemical process to economically separate copper from copper sulfide ore.

PARA.TAB: Under the present method, you put this ore into a large smelter at a high temperature and out the other end you get copper but, unfortunately, you also get hundreds of thousands of tonnes of sulfur dioxide, which eventually becomes acid rain and which has been banned in other countries. If you trap this sulfur dioxide, you end up with sulfuric acid.

To smelt copper in this way requires an enormous capital cost in smelters, usually running into hundreds of millions of dollars. The smelters are very large to get economies of scale. They are costly to run. The one at Port Kembla has been running at a loss for some years. An announcement was made the other day that because of the modifications that have to be made for environmental and other reasons, it may close down next year, with the loss of 440 jobs. Of course, the copper that is processed there would have to go overseas.

Intec has a chemical chloride leaching process which produces very high quality copper—it is 99.99 per cent copper—and elemental sulfur, which can be used for such things as fertilisers. It can also extract gold and other impurities such as bismuth, arsenic and antimony. It can treat lower grade ores than can a smelter; therefore, present sub-economic ore bodies could be utilised. It can treat very complex ores, because the valance on the copper ion is only one plus instead of two pluses. It uses only half the energy. It operates at a very low temperature compared with a smelter—only 85 degrees. Environmental pollution is cut to zero; no sulfur dioxide is produced, only elemental sulfur. It is less costly to run and it can be run on a scale of any size, so you can use it on-site for small deposits. It cuts the freight costs of sending the ore to places like Mount Isa, Port Kembla or wherever.

Worldwide, 100 patents have been taken out on this. I think that it absolutely oozes potential in royalties. Later it could be used for other ore such as lead, zinc and nickel. It sounds almost too good to be true. The world has been searching for a successful chloride leaching process for over 200 years and this small company in Sydney has finally cracked it. Within a short period of time, the partners in this company are going to put a $10 million plant into Port Kembla to test it there. By early 1996, at the latest, they hope to put a $75 million plant into north Parkes which could also treat the ore from Cobar at Girilambone and Cadia.

Many companies are already interested in this—16 companies have already bought in. In fact, Intec is beating them off. They include Australian companies such as BHP Minerals, North Broken Hill Peko and Western Mining; overseas companies such as RTZ, the largest mining house in the world; and Japanese companies such as Sumitomo, Nippon and Mitsui. But, every time an overseas company comes in, it dilutes the Australian equity. Intec would benefit greatly if it could get a government grant—as I believe it is entitled to—to further advance what it is researching.

The IR&D board has five committees. The EIE committee—the engineering, infrastructure and environmental committee—has looked at it on numerous occasions but has always knocked it back. On 20 May last year it said that the grant of $900,000 needed was too large for the potential, the commercial outcome was doubtful and it was not competitive against other projects. There are no other projects in this area. When it was reconsidered in October and December of that year and January and June of this year, it knocked it back for the same reasons.

I have been able to get the committee to look at it again, but it has knocked it back because it said it is now going to be commercially successful and it does not need the money. No matter which way you go you cannot win. I believe that the government should look at this. It has great potential and I believe it is something the government should be associated with. The central west is outraged by the decision because 100 jobs are hanging on it in the town of Parkes. (Time expired)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Victoria: Sale of Fairway Primary School Site

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I must apologise to you for what happened in question time today. When I asked a simple question of the Minister for Schools, Vocational Training and Education (Mr Free), the opposition tried to stall the answer and not allow it to be given. It was a disgraceful display by the opposition. It only goes to show that those on the other side are guilty—guilty of trying to stop the flow of knowledge to the Australian community of exactly what is happening down in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: One of the schools that was mentioned today was the Fairway Primary School in my electorate, which was closed down by Jeffrey Kennett and his henchmen earlier this year. It is being destroyed right at this moment—it has probably been knocked down by now. The way he has people working down there, they are probably still working now. When I visited the school last week there were nails and bits of wood lying around everywhere, asbestos around the place and no security around the actual building.

Obviously, the Victorian occupational health and safety legislation is not working at the Fairway Primary School site. That is a disgraceful situation for the actual residents who live around there. The asbestos that was coming out of the roof and the walls—it was a fairly old school—was being blown all around that area. The local residents have taken this matter up by circulating a petition to try to do something to control it. The people who are actually pulling it down do not look to me as though they have had too much expertise in the destruction of buildings. I think it is one of those jobs where things are being done on the cheap. This was a great state school which Jeffrey Kennett and the Minister for Education, Don Hayward, have put out of business.

Fairway Primary School is one of the many schools that has been closed in Victoria. I do not hear too much from representatives of the National Party in relation to the closure of schools in the country. What is happening in the country areas is also a disgrace. The country schools, the train lines and the hospitals are all being closed down. But do we hear anything from cockies corner? No, they are silent. Why? Because Jeffrey Kennett has them scared. He has not got me scared.

As a result of the closure of Fairway Primary School, the children now have to cross a railway crossing, which is at the end of a main road, to get to the other school. This crossing is a death trap. There are young primary school children having to cross this railway line, and sooner or later something is going to happen. There is only one person who will be blamed for it—Jeffrey Kennett. Some of the kids are taken across by bus. That has been quite well received by the parents and residents of the area. However, many young children are still crossing over this railway line. They have to as a result of their school having been closed down and their being forced to go to another school.

The guilty party in Victoria—that is, the Liberal Party, which is in government—is in real strife. One only has to look at the polls in Victoria to be assured that the Liberal Party will not be voted back in at the next election. It will not get back because of the actions it is taking in relation to state schools, secondary schools and technical schools all over Victoria. It has run down the education system. It is all right for the people who can afford to send their children to private schools. They will get a good education. However, the state schools are just being run down.

There is immense pressure on the teachers in state schools. Good teachers have left the system. Other teachers are in there trying to do their best, but they are being hampered all the time by the Victorian education department. They are not allowed to speak out. If they speak out, they get some sort of sanction put on them. They might get demoted to some other part of Victoria.

The Victorian government has state school teachers in such a bind that they are afraid to speak out in case they jeopardise their position. This has all come about because of the Liberal Party's manic obsession to close state schools and ship people into private schools. The Fairway Primary School was a good school. It should not have been closed down. What it is doing is putting not only the lives of primary school children in danger but also the lives of residents of that area in danger. I imagine that the government will soon sell the area off and turn it into apartments. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Earlier today the member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly) raised important new evidence about the long-running case of Mrs Sylvia Faulkner. But he did not get the chance to tell parliament the full story of how the Attorney-General's Department, and in particular the Australian Government Solicitor, dealt with his FOI request. Even now the Attorney-General's Department finds it hard to part with some documents on its files.

PARA.TAB: The member for Bradfield lodged his FOI request at the end of January 1994. The Office of the Australian Government Solicitor promised the documents by the end of March. A month after the expiry of the processing period the member for Bradfield appealed to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on the grounds of deemed refusal. On 11 May the Australian Government Solicitor notified its decision on the documents. At a directions hearing on 16 May 1994, it claimed it had been very generous in its decision on the release of the documents.

In August, the AGS forwarded material it considered non-contentious. In addition, the AGS also gratuitously forwarded the New South Wales court judgment and which drew particular attention to the judge's finding that Mr Faulkner emerged from the case with no credibility. This can only be taken as a clumsy attempt to dissuade the member for Bradfield from pursuing the Faulkner issue.

On 15 September, the AGS forwarded the decision maker's affidavit, which claimed additional grounds for exemption under section 41 of the act. Yet on 22 September at the AAT hearing the AGS filed a new affidavit which dropped most of the section 41 exemptions. The AGS then argued to the tribunal that most of the material remaining in the dispute was irrelevant. Given the AGS's track record, the AAT was asked to rule on whether or not this actually was irrelevant. It decided overwhelmingly in favour of the applicant.

The material that the AGS claimed was irrelevant—and which it has now been forced to release—relates to discussions of indemnity for Mr Flint, a witness in the case, and the bearing of former Brigadier Flint's testimony on his pension and, most pertinently, records the remarks of the Commonwealth as `buying truth'. One item to turn up in documents connected with the FOI application was a file note recording the AGS's consultation with the Solicitor-General on this FOI request. It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Griffith—
the Solicitor-General—
said that he had no objection to release of the documents. He suggested that a copy of the judgment could also be provided `with compliments'.

The Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) should be appalled not only that the Solicitor-General sought to deter an FOI applicant but also that the person who recommended limits on Sylvia Faulkner's legal assistance clearly holds prejudices against the Faulkners. Material uncovered by this application revealed that the Commonwealth government has engaged in an attempted cover-up. It has engaged in what amounts to a conspiracy to pervert the course of justice. The Attorney-General needs to answer for this.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Following the Army board of inquiry into the death of Private Adrian Cave, has proper and just disciplinary action been taken against those who were found to have contributed directly or indirectly to his death; if not, has the integrity of the Army's internal investigative and disciplinary processes and reports, in particular the board of inquiry's report, been damaged.
(2) Were fourteen criminal charges laid against the officer-in-charge of the live firing practice exercise in which Private Cave was killed; if so, were all the charges dismissed; if so, why.
(3) Has another member of the Australian Defence Force been killed recently on a live firing range.
(4) Will the Minister institute a general inquiry into the Army's conduct of live firing ranges.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is considered that, having regard to the disciplinary and administrative action taken against certain individuals, appropriate and proper disciplinary action was taken in response to the findings of the Board of Inquiry into Private Cave's unfortunate death. The integrity of the Army's internal investigative and disciplinary processes is therefore not in question and has not been damaged.

(2) Yes. The officer in charge of the practice in which Private Cave was killed did face a General Court Martial to answer 14 charges relating to the activity. The member was found not guilty on seven charges as there was no case to answer, following submissions by the member's defending officer. The court martial found the member not guilty on the remaining seven charges. I do not intend to detail the reasons why the member was found not guilty on each charge. However, you can be assured that due legal consideration was given to each charge and that on the basis of evidence provided the court found insufficient justification to deliver a guilty verdict on any charge.
(3) Yes.

(4) No. Any incident which results in the death of an individual on a live firing range is comprehensively investigated. If, as a result of the investigation, it is identified that a weakness exists in the training or conduct of a live firing range, actions are taken to rectify the deficiency. I am satisfied that this system of control is sufficient to minimise the possibility of death or injury to member's of our Defence Force.
